name: Counting
description: 1, 2, 3, let's count! In this unit, we're going to take our counting skills to the next level. We'll count pictures, objects, and even compare different numbers. By the end of the unit, you'll be able to count all the way up to 120 like it's no big deal!

name: Addition and subtraction intro
description: Sure, you can count to 10, but did you know you can add and subtract numbers within 10 too? It might sound tricky, but don't worry-- you're going to have a blast learning all the different ways numbers can work together. Ready to put your thinking cap on?

name: Place value (tens and hundreds)
description: Welcome to the wonderful world of place value! In this unit, you'll learn all about how numbers are put together-- from the hundreds place all the way down to the ones. You'll practice regrouping whole numbers, comparing three-digit numbers, and more.

name: Addition and subtraction within 20
description: Math can be a blast! In this unit, you'll learn about adding and subtracting numbers up to 20. That might sound tricky, but you'll have all the tools to help you out. Place value blocks, ten frames, arrays, and number lines can all make solving words problems a snap.

name: Addition and subtraction within 100
description: In this unit, you'll learn about adding and subtracting numbers within 100. But don't worry, we're going to make it super fun. You'll practice skip counting by 5s and 10s, use colorful place value blocks, and explore number lines. Plus, you'll solve cool word problems and even some 2-step challenges.

name: Addition and subtraction within 1000
description: Adding and subtracting 2- and 3-digit numbers might sound hard, but don't worry--in second grade, you'll learn all the strategies! With tools like place value blocks, number lines, and breaking apart numbers, you'll be solving equations like a math whiz in no time.

name: Measurement and data
description: Buckle up! We're zooming into the world of measurement and data. Get ready to learn how to measure in inches, feet, meters, and centimeters. We'll make different graphs to see how data can tell us all kinds of stories. Plus, we'll practice telling time on a number line and clock!

name: Geometry
description: Are you ready to jump into the world of geometry? You'll learn all about shapes—how to name them, identify them, and compare them to one another. From circles to rectangles, you'll be a shape master in no time!

name: Add and subtract within 20
description: In this unit, we'll learn how to add and subtract small numbers in a fun and interactive way, develop confidence with these basic math skills, and build a strong foundation for future learning.

name: Place value
description: You know that the number 123 isn't the same as the number 321, but do you really know why? In this unit on place value, we're going to explore what each digit means, how to break down numbers into their different place values, and how to compare numbers to see which is bigger or smaller.

name: Add and subtract within 100
description: Sharpen your pencils and get ready to flex your math muscles! In this unit, you'll dive into addition and subtraction within 100. Whether you're using number lines, place value blocks, or solving word problems, you'll become a math master in no time.

name: Add and subtract within 1,000
description: Get ready to take your addition and subtraction skills to the next level! In this unit, you'll be working with numbers all the way up to 1000. We'll learn how to use number lines, place value blocks, and groups of 10 or 100 to help us out.

name: Money and time
description: Do you know what time it is? Time to learn all about money and clocks! This unit will teach you everything you need to know about counting change and keeping track of the hours and minutes in a day.

name: Measurement
description: How long is a pencil? How tall is a chair? In this unit, you'll learn the tools you need to answer these questions and more. From inches to meters, you'll become a measurement master in no time.

name: Data
description: Sometimes, numbers can be confusing. But with picture graphs, bar graphs, and line plots, we can turn all those digits into a story that's easy to understand.

name: Geometry
description: Are you ready to dive into the world of shapes? In this geometry unit, you'll learn all about squares, rectangles, and more. Plus, you'll find out how to split them into equal parts for even more fun!

name: Intro to multiplication
description: Ready for some mental gymnastics? In this unit on multiplication, you'll learn how to combine equal groups of numbers to find the total - and even how to use arrays to draw out what you're doing. You'll learn all about what it means to combine equal groups of numbers to level up your math skills.

name: 1-digit multiplication
description: What's 2 times 5? How about 4 times 7? If you're not sure, don't fear! Khan Academy is here. You'll learn all about the distributive property and how it can help you visualize multiplying numbers in a whole new way so you can multiply like a pro.

name: Addition, subtraction, and estimation
description: The world of math is full of twists and turns but luckily, this unit on addition, subtraction, and estimation is here to help you navigate. Whether it's mastering the art of rounding or learning how to regroup, Khan Academy is your secret weapon for success.

name: Intro to division
description: Now that you know all about multiplication, it's time to divide and conquer! In this unit, you'll learn the basics of division and how it's connected to everything you've already learned about multiplication.

name: Understand fractions
description: Come explore the wonderful world of fractions! In our 3rd grade unit, you'll learn how to break numbers into bite-sized pieces, plot them on a number line, and show them off in a tape diagram.

name: Equivalent fractions and comparing fractions
description: You already know what fractions are, but did you know that some fractions that look different are actually the same? There's more to these pieces than meets the eye. Dive into this unit to learn the secrets of equivalent fractions and how to compare them!

name: More with multiplication and division
description: If you're ready to take your math skills to the next level, this is the unit for you! You'll learn the nitty gritty of multiplication and division, master the associative property, and even figure out how to use letters and symbols to represent numbers. Plus, you'll tackle some cool tricks—like multiplying by 10!

name: Arithmetic patterns and problem solving
description: Math isn't just about numbers - it's about patterns, too! In this unit, you'll figure out how to spot patterns in different types of problems and learn cool strategies to solve them.  You'll tackle word problems, master estimation, and learn to write expressions like a pro.

name: Quadrilaterals
description: With four sides and four angles, quadrilaterals might seem pretty straight-forward. But there's a lot more to these shapes than you might think!  In this unit, you'll learn all about these four-sided shapes and hone your skills at identifying, analyzing and classifying them.

name: Area
description: Everything around us has a measurable area from the floor we walk on to the walls of our rooms. In this unit, we'll be exploring area! We'll learn some handy ways to figure out just how much space a shape covers--from counting squares, to multiplying, to breaking shapes down into smaller pieces. Let's get measuring!

name: Perimeter
description: Get ready to draw the line--the perimeter line, that is! This unit will walk you through everything you need to know about measuring the distance around shapes and finding out how big (or small) they really are. Who knew math could be so much fun?

name: Time
description: Tick, tock, it's time to rock! In this unit on time, we'll practice reading clocks, using a number line to figure out the hours and minutes, and discovering how much time has passed between different moments.

name: Measurement
description: How heavy is that rock? How much water can that jar hold? These are just a few of the questions we'll tackle in this unit as we learn all about mass and volume!

name: Represent and interpret data
description: So you've collected lots of cool data? Time to learn how to make it look even cooler! In this unit, you'll explore different types of graphs - from picture graphs to bar graphs to line plots. With these tools in your back pocket, you'll be able to show everyone just what your data means.

name: Place value
description: It's time to master place value! In this unit, you'll use blocks and tables to learn all about expanding, standardizing, and writing numbers. You'll also sharpen your skills in comparing and regrouping whole numbers.

name: Addition, subtraction, and estimation
description: Addition and subtraction are key skills for any math whiz. In this unit, you'll sharpen those skills by working with multi-digit numbers. You'll also learn how to round and estimate, so you can quickly make calculations even when you don't have a calculator handy.

name: Multiply by 1-digit numbers
description: This unit will teach you all about multiplying by 1-digit numbers using the distributive property, area models, and multiples of 10. With these tools in your math toolkit, you'll be a multiplication master in no time. So what are you waiting for? Let's dive in!

name: Multiply by 2-digit numbers
description: Just when you thought multiplication couldn't get any more exciting, we're throwing 2-digit numbers into the mix! We'll explore different strategies like area models, partial products, and estimation to make sure you're ready to multiply any 2-digit number by another 2-digit number!

name: Division
description: Do you like breaking things apart? Then you're going to love learning about division! We'll use place value, area models, and estimation techniques to make dividing by 1-digit numbers a breeze. In this unit, you will even get the inside scoop on what to do when there's a pesky remainder left over.

name: Factors, multiples and patterns
description: In this unit, you'll learn all about how numbers can be broken down into different factor pairs. You'll also get to investigate which numbers are prime and which are composite. But that's not all! You'll also get to explore how shapes and numbers can be arranged in different patterns!

name: Equivalent fractions and comparing fractions
description: You already know that fractions can be broken into parts, but did you know that different fractions can be equivalent? In this lesson, you'll learn all about equivalent fractions and how to compare them. With the help of models, number lines, and benchmark fractions, you'll be a fraction master in no time!

name: Add and subtract fractions
description: It's time to tackle fractions! From common denominators to unlike denominators, this unit will teach you everything you need to know to add and subtract them confidently. Get ready to show those fractions who's boss!

name: Multiply fractions
description: Do you love solving math puzzles? Then you're going to love learning how to multiply fractions! From multiplying fractions and whole numbers to using fraction models and number lines, this unit will give you all the tools you need to multiply any type of fraction - including mixed numbers!

name: Understand decimals
description: Ready to tackle decimals? You'll be amazed at how easy they are to understand when you use grids and number lines. Once you know how to place decimals to tenths and hundredths place on the number line, you'll learn how to compare them and write decimals as fractions.

name: Plane figures
description: In this unit, you'll get to dive into the exciting world of plane figures! You'll learn all about lines, line segments, and rays. You'll even get to experiment with angles and find out how they make shapes look different. Plus, you'll get to explore some cool concepts like parallel and perpendicular lines.

name: Measuring angles
description: Have you ever wondered how to measure the size of an angle? Get ready to dive into an exciting world of protractors, circles, and benchmark angles! You'll learn all about different types of angles, how to draw them, and even how to break them down into smaller parts.

name: Area and perimeter
description: Ready to put your math skills to the test? In this lesson, you'll learn all about area and perimeter! You'll explore how to find the area and perimeter of a rectangle. You'll practice labeling rectangles with given information, and you'll even get to flex your problem-solving muscles with some word problems!

name: Units of measurement
description: Did you know units of measurement are all around us? From how much milk is in your cereal bowl to how far you run in gym class, these measurements help us make sense of the world. In this unit, you'll learn how to estimate and convert measurements for mass, volume, and length.

name: Decimal place value
description: Put on your math detective hat and dive into this unit on decimal place value. You'll learn how to locate decimals on a number line, see which ones are bigger or smaller, and round them to the nearest whole number.

name: Add decimals
description: Want to become a decimal dynamo? This unit will help you get there! You'll learn how to add decimals to tenths and hundredths, and discover how common fractions can give you a leg up.

name: Subtract decimals
description: You've got adding decimals down, but what about subtracting them? In this unit, you'll learn how to do just that, mastering the tenths and hundredths places. And with the help of some handy hundredths blocks visuals, you'll be a decimal subtraction pro in no time.

name: Add and subtract fractions
description: It's time to tackle fractions! From common denominators to unlike denominators, this unit will teach you everything you need to know to add and subtract them confidently. Get ready to show those fractions who's boss!

name: Multi-digit multiplication and division
description: Ready to take your multiplication and division skills to the next level? This unit will show you how to tackle multi-digit problems like a pro, using estimation, the standard algorithm, and some handy tricks with factors of 10.

name: Multiply fractions
description: Why have just one way to multiply fractions when you can have four? Learn how to use number lines, the fraction model, the area model, and word problems to multiply fractions like a pro.

name: Divide fractions
description: Let's tackle dividing fractions! From breaking up fractions by whole numbers to dividing whole numbers by fractions, we'll learn it all. Plus, we'll practice with word problems and visuals to really nail down the concepts.

name: Multiply decimals
description: When it comes to multiplying decimals, there's more than one way to get the job done. Explore different strategies in this unit and find the one that works best for you. From estimation, to area models, to grids, one of these is bound to help you master decimals multiplication.

name: Divide decimals
description: You've mastered adding, subtracting, and multiplying decimals, but now it's time to conquer dividing them too! This unit will take your skills to the next level as you learn how to tackle dividing whole numbers by decimals and decimals by whole numbers. With helpful visuals like fraction models and number lines!

name: Powers of ten
description: Math is all about patterns, and there's no better place to see that than with powers of ten. In this unit, you'll learn the patterns in multiplying and dividing by 10, 100, and 1000. Get ready to zoom through zeros!

name: Volume
description: Looking to become a volume virtuoso? This unit has you covered! We'll explore how to measure volume with unit cubes, work with rectangular prisms, and break down trickier shapes to find volume. Get ready to dive into some seriously voluminous learning!

name: Coordinate plane
description: Get ready to map out some math! In this unit, you'll learn all about the coordinate plane, plotting and identifying points, locating coordinates and finding out the distance between them. Buckle up and get ready for a geometric adventure!

name: Algebraic thinking
description: Math is all about problem solving, and this unit will challenge you to use your algebraic thinking skills in new ways. You'll learn how parentheses can change the whole meaning of an algebraic expression by practice evaluating, translating, and creating your own expressions.

name: Converting units of measure
description: Just as there's more than one way to measure something, there's more than one unit of measure! In this unit, you'll learn all about converting between different units of measure, time to metric and US customary measurements, so you can solve any word problem thrown your way.

name: Line plots
description: Line plots aren't just for whole numbers! In this unit, you'll learn how to use them to graph fractions, and then put your skills to the test by interpreting the data, and solving some puzzling problems.

name: Properties of shapes
description: Different shapes have different properties, and in this unit, you'll get to know them all. From triangles to quadrilaterals to polygons, you'll learn how to tell them apart and understand what makes each one unique.

name: Ratios
description: Ratios let us see how two values relate, especially when the values grow or shrink together. From baking recipes to sports, these concepts find their way into our lives on a daily basis.

name: Arithmetic with rational numbers
description: The most fundamental branch of math is arithmetic operations. It consists of adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing numbers. By this point, performing these operations on whole numbers might be a piece of cake, but now we'll mix those numbers up with decimals and fractions. Get ready to slice and dice!

name: Rates and percentages
description: Rates and percentages are a new and exciting real world application of arithmetic! They come up frequently in everyday life—from figuring out sale prices to calculating tips at restaurants. These are concepts you can actually use every day!

name: Exponents and order of operations
description: You've already heard of adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing. Ready for a new operation? Exponents take multiplication to a whole new level.

name: Negative numbers
description: Negative numbers are a necessary part of our understanding of mathematics and the world. Negative does not mean "bad." It's just changing the same amount, but in the opposite direction, like getting cooler instead of warmer. Absolute value tells us the amount of the change without the direction.

name: Variables & expressions
description: A variable is a symbol that represents a value, often one that changes, like how long you've been awake. Learn ways that we can change an expression's value (such as by changing the values of its variables) or keep the value the same (such as with the distributive property).

name: Equations & inequalities
description: Solving equations is a superpower. It means we can model a situation with an equation in any way that makes sense to us, even with an unknown value in the middle. Inequalities are for situations with many true options, like how many pages I can send in my letter using just 1 stamp.

name: Plane figures
description: In this unit, you'll become an expert on plane figures! You'll learn how to find the area of parallelograms and triangles, and even take on the challenge of composite figures. You'll also get some practice finding missing lengths and breaking down shapes into simpler parts. Get ready to show those plane figures who's boss!

name: Coordinate plane
description: A coordinate plane is a two-dimensional grid, typically with an x-axis and a y-axis, that allows us to visually represent and locate points in space. Just like on the number line, the coordinate plane can show positive and negative values. Just look for their position to the left, right, above, or below the origin.

name: 3D figures
description: 2D figures have area and perimeter to describe the measurements of their interiors and exteriors. With 3D figures, we use volume and surface area for the same ideas. We'll find fractional volumes using cubes with fractional side lengths. For surface area, we'll add the areas of each outside face.

name: Data and statistics
description: Let's collect and use data to make smart predictions about the world around you! You'll learn how to compare outcomes, to visualize the shape of the data, and to pick a graph type that shows its key features.

name: Negative numbers: addition and subtraction
description: Add and subtract negative numbers, and see how absolute value can be used to find the distance between any two numbers on the number line.

name: Negative numbers: multiplication and division
description: Learn to multiply and divide negative numbers. Once you've got the basics down, we'll revisit fractions, exponents, and order of operations but this time with negatives!

name: Fractions, decimals, & percentages
description: In these tutorials, we'll explore the number system. We'll convert fractions to decimals, operate on numbers in different forms, meet complex fractions, and identify types of numbers. We'll also solve interesting word problems involving percentages (discounts, taxes, and tip calculations).

name: Rates & proportional relationships
description: Learn all about proportional relationships. How are they connected to ratios and rates? What do their graphs look like? What types of word problems can we solve with proportions?

name: Expressions, equations, & inequalities
description: Bring on the algebra! Learn how to manipulate expressions and solve equations and inequalities.

name: Geometry
description: Geometric shapes are all around us. The world is built with them. In this series of tutorials and exercises you'll become familiar with Euclidean geometry and terms like segments, scale drawings, parts of a circle, area, volume, angles, and geometric figures.

name: Statistics and probability
description: This introduction to probability and statistics explores probability models, sample spaces, compound events, random samples, and a whole lot more.

name: Numbers and operations
description: You already know lots of types of numbers, like integers, decimals, and fractions. You also can use several operations, like subtraction and absolute value. Let's learn about another type of numbers, irrational numbers, and deepen our understanding of the power operation.

name: Solving equations with one unknown
description: Let's take your equation-solving skills to the next level! You'll learn all the strategies you need to confidently tackle problems with variables on both sides, parentheses, and more. Plus, you'll get plenty of practice with word problems to really solidify your understanding.

name: Linear equations and functions
description: When distances, prices, or any other quantity in our world changes at a constant rate, we can use linear functions to model them. Let's learn how different representations, including graphs and equations, of these useful functions reveal characteristics of the situation.

name: Systems of equations
description: If one line is useful, let's see what we can do with two lines. In this unit, we learn how to write systems of equations, solve those systems, and interpret what those solutions mean in a real-world context.

name: Geometry
description: In this topic, we'll learn about special angles, such as angles between intersecting lines and triangle angles. Next, we'll learn about the Pythagorean theorem. Finally, we'll find volume of curved 3D shapes like spheres, cones, and cylinders.

name: Geometric transformations
description: We say two numerical expressions are equivalent when they have the same value. How do we decide when two shapes are the same? We'll explore some moves, like flips and slides, that keep a shape the same, and some other moves that change it.

name: Data and modeling
description: Linear models are great, but real life data doesn't always line up perfectly. Lines of best fit come to the rescue to find a model that's closest to the data. We'll also look for patterns in catagorical data. Do neighborhoods with farmers' markets have different health outcomes than those without?

name: Algebra foundations
description: Why did humans invent algebra in the first place? Let's look at the history and beauty of algebra, and review some fundamental ideas and tools we'll use throughout the course.

name: Solving equations & inequalities
description: There are lots of strategies we can use to solve equations. Let's explore some different ways to solve equations and inequalities. We'll also see what it takes for an equation to have no solution, or infinite solutions.

name: Working with units
description: In you are in the United States, you might see a car advertise its fuel efficiency as 50 miles per gallon. Somewhere else, you'd probably see it called 4.7 liters per 100 kilometers. Let's practice solving real world problems like this involving units.

name: Linear equations & graphs
description: Let's explore different ways to find and visualize slopes and intercepts, and how these concepts can help us solve real-world problems.

name: Forms of linear equations
description: We can write linear equations in different forms to reveal different features of the scenarios they describe. Let's get clever.

name: Systems of equations
description: If one line is useful, let's see what we can do with two lines. In this unit, we learn how to write systems of equations, solve those systems, and interpret what those solutions mean in a real-world context.

name: Inequalities (systems & graphs)
description: If it takes someone in a cooking competition 30 seconds to chop an onion and 18 seconds to chop a carrot, and their goal is to chop at least 20 of these vegetables in a time limit of 540 seconds, what can they do? Use a system of linear inequalities, of course.

name: Functions
description: A function is like a machine that takes an input and gives an output. Let's explore how we can graph, analyze, and create different types of functions.

name: Sequences
description: Sequences are a special type of function that are useful for describing patterns. In this unit, we'll see how sequences let us jump forwards or backwards in patterns to solve problems.

name: Absolute value & piecewise functions
description: Piecewise functions piece together different functions. Absolute value graphs make a V shape, but why do they do that? Let's explore how to make some new and interesting types of graphs.

name: Exponents & radicals
description: Let's review exponent rules and level up what we know about roots. The square root is nice, but let's learn about higher-order roots like the cube root (or 3rd root).

name: Exponential growth & decay
description: What does it mean for something to change exponentially? Let's learn about a new family of functions, and use these exponential functions to analyze real-world scenarios.

name: Quadratics: Multiplying & factoring
description: We can factor numbers like 24 into 2x12, or 3x8, or 4x6...But how can we factor algebraic expressions? We'll see that it's a lot like a puzzle.

name: Quadratic functions & equations
description: We've seen linear and exponential functions, and now we're ready for quadratic functions. We'll explore how these functions and the parabolas they produce can be used to solve real-world problems.

name: Irrational numbers
description: What does it mean for a number to be irrational? Let's find out. The answer may surprise you.

name: Creativity in algebra
description: We sat down with some experts to ask them questions like, "Why is creativity important in algebra?" Let's see what they had to say!

name: Performing transformations
description:
In this topic you will learn about the most useful math concept for creating video game graphics: geometric transformations, specifically translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations.

You will learn how to perform the transformations, and how to map one figure into another using these transformations.

name: Transformation properties and proofs
description: Let's carefully define translations, reflections, rotations, and dilations. What stays the same when we transform figures?

name: Congruence
description: Learn what it means for two figures to be congruent, and how to determine whether two figures are congruent or not. Use this immensely important concept to prove various geometric theorems about triangles and parallelograms.

name: Similarity
description: Learn what it means for two figures to be similar, and how to determine whether two figures are similar or not. Use this concept to prove geometric theorems and solve some problems with polygons.

name: Right triangles & trigonometry
description: Triangles are not always right (although they are never wrong), but when they are it opens up an exciting world of possibilities.  Not only are right triangles cool in their own right (pun intended), they are the basis of very important ideas in analytic geometry (the distance between two points in space) and trigonometry.

name: Analytic geometry
description: In analytic geometry, also known as coordinate geometry, we think about geometric objects on the coordinate plane. For example, we can see that opposite sides of a parallelogram are parallel by writing a linear equation for each side and seeing that the slopes are the same.

name: Conic sections
description: The cross-sections of a cone form several interesting curved shapes—circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas. Use the distance formula to relate the geometric features of the figures to their algebraic equations.

name: Circles
description: Explore, prove, and apply important properties of circles that have to do with things like arc length, radians, inscribed angles, and tangents.

name: Solid geometry
description: Extend your knowledge about two-dimensional shapes to three dimensions!

name: Polynomial arithmetic
description: We'll explore the connection between polynomials and the integers, through adding, subtracting, and multiplying polynomials. This prepares us for factoring and dividing polynomials, and paves the way for complex modeling in fields like physics, engineering, and finance.

name: Complex numbers
description: Welcome to the world of imaginary and complex numbers. We'll learn what imaginary and complex numbers are, how to perform arithmetic operations with them, represent them graphically on the complex plane, and apply these concepts to solve quadratic equations in new ways.

name: Polynomial factorization
description: Let's get equipped with a variety of key strategies for breaking down higher degree polynomials. From taking out common factors to using special products, we'll build a strong foundation to help us investigate polynomial functions and prove identities.

name: Polynomial division
description: After we have added, subtracted, and multiplied polynomials, it's time to divide them! This will prove to be a little bit more sophisticated. It turns out that not every polynomial division results in a polynomial. When it doesn't, we end up with a remainder (just like with integer division!).

name: Polynomial graphs
description: In this unit, we will use everything that we know about polynomials in order to analyze their graphical behavior. Specifically, we will find polynomials' zeros (i.e., x-intercepts) and analyze how they behave as the x-values become infinitely positive or infinitely negative (i.e., end-behavior).

name: Rational exponents and radicals
description: We previously learned about integer powers—first positive and then also negative. But what does it mean to raise a number to the 2.5 power? In Algebra 2, we extend previous concepts to include rational powers. We'll define how they work, and use them to rewrite exponential expressions in various ways.

name: Exponential models
description: Let's revisit exponential growth and decay. We'll learn how to construct, interpret, and apply exponential functions to model a variety of real-world contexts, from modeling population growth and radioactive decay to interpreting interest rates.

name: Logarithms
description: Logarithms are the inverses of exponents. They allow us to solve challenging exponential equations, and they are a good excuse to dive deeper into the relationship between a function and its inverse.

name: Transformations of functions
description: We can think graphs of absolute value and quadratic functions as transformations of the parent functions |x| and x². Importantly, we can extend this idea to include transformations of any function whatsoever! This fascinating concept allows us to graph many other types of functions, like square/cube root, exponential and logarithmic functions.

name: Equations
description: Let's tackle a greater variety of equations, like rational and radical equations. We'll see that sometimes, we get solutions that aren't really solutions at all, called extraneous solutions. We'll also solve more advanced systems, and learn how we can use graphs to estimate a solution for any kind of equation!

name: Trigonometry
description: Let's extend trigonometric ratios sine, cosine, and tangent into functions that are defined for all real numbers. You might be surprised at how we can use the behavior of those functions to model real-world situations involving carnival rides and planetary distances.

name: Modeling
description: Let's dive even deeper into the world of modeling. We'll take our knowledge about all the different function types we were exposed to so far, and use it to model and analyze various phenomena, from heart rates to business profits.

name: Algebra foundations
description: This unit is an overview of some fundamental ideas and tools we'll be using throughout the course.

name: Solving equations & inequalities
description: In this unit, we learn how to solve linear equations and inequalities that contain a single variable. For example, we'll solve equations like 2(x+3)=(4x-1)/2+7 and inequalities like 5x-2≥2(x-1).

name: Working with units
description: In this unit, we start to think about some general modeling concerns before we dive into modeling situations with different kinds of functions and equations throughout the course.

name: Linear equations & graphs
description: In this unit, we learn about linear equations and how we can use their graphs to solve problems.

name: Forms of linear equations
description: In this unit, we learn how to write linear equations in different forms to reveal different features of their relationships.

name: Systems of equations
description: In this unit, we learn how to write systems of equations, solve those systems, and interpret what those solutions mean.

name: Inequalities (systems & graphs)
description: In this unit, we study inequalities like x+2y>5 and graph them. This helps us see their solutions. We also explore systems of inequalities (multiple inequalities at the same time) and use them to describe real-world situations.

name: Functions
description: In this unit, we learn about functions, which are mathematical entities that assign unique outputs to given inputs. We'll evaluate, graph, analyze, and create various types of functions.

name: Scatterplots
description: Scatterplots show us relationships and patterns in data, and we use those patterns to make predictions.

name: Data distributions
description: Data makes more sense when we graph it and summarize it with numbers.

name: Two-way tables
description: Two-way tables show us relationships between categorical variables.

name: Sequences
description: In this unit, we learn about the various ways in which we can define sequences. We'll construct arithmetic and geometric sequences to describe patterns and use those sequences to solve problems.

name: Exponents & radicals
description: In this unit, we review exponent rules and learn about higher-order roots like the cube root (or 3rd root). We'll learn how to calculate these roots and simplify algebraic expressions with radicals.

name: Exponential growth & decay
description: In this unit, we learn how to construct, analyze, graph, and interpret basic exponential functions of the form f(x)=a⋅bˣ.

name: Performing transformations
description:
In this topic you will learn about the most useful math concept for creating video game graphics: geometric transformations, specifically translations, rotations, reflections, and dilations.

You will learn how to perform the transformations, and how to map one figure into another using these transformations.

name: Transformation properties and proofs
description: Let's carefully define translations, reflections, rotations, and dilations. What stays the same when we transform figures?

name: Congruence
description: Learn what it means for two figures to be congruent, and how to determine whether two figures are congruent or not. Use this immensely important concept to prove various geometric theorems about triangles and parallelograms.

name: Analytic geometry
description: In analytic geometry, also known as coordinate geometry, we think about geometric objects on the coordinate plane. For example, we can see that opposite sides of a parallelogram are parallel by writing a linear equation for each side and seeing that the slopes are the same.

name: Absolute value & piecewise functions
description: In this unit, we learn how to solve and graph absolute value and piecewise equations.

name: Quadratics: Multiplying & factoring
description: There are a lot of great ways to multiply and factor integers. In this unit, we'll build on those strategies to learn how to multiply and factor algebraic expressions.

name: Quadratic functions & equations
description: In this unit, we learn how to solve quadratic equations, and how to analyze and graph quadratic functions.

name: Irrational numbers
description: In this unit, we learn about irrational numbers and how to identify them.

name: Complex numbers
description: Complex numbers are built on the idea that we can define the number i (called "the imaginary unit") to be the principal square root of -1, or a solution to the equation x²=-1. From this starting point evolves a rich and exciting world of the number system that encapsulates everything we have known before: integers, rational, and real numbers.

name: Rational exponents and radicals
description: In middle school, students learned about integer powers—first positive and then also negative. In Algebra 2, we extend this concept to include rational powers. We will define how they work, and use them to rewrite exponential expressions in various ways.

name: Exponential models
description: In Algebra 1, students worked with simple exponential models to describe various real-world situations. In Algebra 2, we go deeper and study models that are more elaborate.

name: Similarity
description: Learn what it means for two figures to be similar, and how to determine whether two figures are similar or not. Use this concept to prove geometric theorems and solve some problems with polygons.

name: Right triangles & trigonometry
description: Triangles are not always right (although they are never wrong), but when they are it opens up an exciting world of possibilities.  Not only are right triangles cool in their own right (pun intended), they are the basis of very important ideas in analytic geometry (the distance between two points in space) and trigonometry.

name: Solid geometry
description: Extend your knowledge about two-dimensional shapes to three dimensions!

name: Circles
description: Explore, prove, and apply important properties of circles that have to do with things like arc length, radians, inscribed angles, and tangents.

name: Conic sections
description: Learn about two basic conic sections and their equations: Circle and Parabola.

name: Probability
description: Few things are certain in life. Probability gives us an idea of the likelihood or unlikelihood of different outcomes.

name: Polynomial arithmetic
description: In Mathematics III, students learn about the analog between polynomials and the integers, through adding, subtracting, and multiplying polynomials. This also paves the way for factoring and dividing polynomials.

name: Polynomial factorization
description: In Mathematics II, students rewrote (factored) quadratic expressions as the product of two linear factors. This helped them learn about the behavior of quadratic functions. In Mathematics III, we extend this idea to rewrite polynomials in degrees higher than 2 as products of linear factors. This will help us investigate polynomial functions. It also allows us to prove polynomial identities, which are mathematical statements that describe numerical relationships.

name: Polynomial division
description: After we have added, subtracted, and multiplied polynomials, it's time to divide them! This will prove to be a little bit more sophisticated. It turns out that not every polynomial division results in a polynomial. When it doesn't, we end up with a remainder (just like with integer division!).

name: Polynomial graphs
description: In this unit, we will use everything that we know about polynomials in order to analyze their graphical behavior. Specifically, we will find polynomials' zeros (i.e., x-intercepts) and analyze how they behave as the x-values become infinitely positive or infinitely negative (i.e., end-behavior).

name: Logarithms
description: Logarithms are the inverses of exponents. They allow us to solve hairy exponential equations, and they are a good excuse to dive deeper into the relationship between a function and its inverse.

name: Transformations of functions
description: In Mathematics II, students reasoned about graphs of absolute value and quadratic functions by thinking of them as transformations of the parent functions |x| and x². In this unit, we extend this idea to include transformations of any function whatsoever. This fascinating concept allows us to graph many other types of functions, like square/cube root, exponential and logarithmic functions.

name: Equations
description: In Mathematics I and II, students solves linear and quadratic equations, and learned how the two processes are based on the same logical principles. In this unit, we extend these processes to solve a greater variety of equations, like rational and radical equations. We learn that we may sometimes get extraneous solutions. We also solve systems that include quadratic equations, and learn how we can use graphs to estimate a solution for any kind of equation!

name: Trigonometry
description: In Mathematics II, students learned about the trigonometric ratios sine, cosine, and tangent. In this unit, we extend these ideas into functions that are defined for all real numbers! We learn about the behavior of those functions and use them to model real-world situations.

name: Modeling
description: This unit dives deeper into the world of modeling. We will take our knowledge about all the different function types we were exposed to so far, and use it to model and analyze various phenomena.

name: Study Design
description: Getting reliable data is vital if we want to make correct conclusions.The process of collecting data through studies involves sampling, observations, surveys, and experiments.

name: Binomial probability
description: If you roll five dice, what’s the probability that three of them show a 6? In a group of 20 strangers, what’s the probability that more than half of them were born in the summer? Learn about binomial probability to answer these types of problems.

name: Normal distributions
description: A Normal distribution is a very special and common distribution that is fundamental to learning about statistics. Normal distributions describe many real world phenomena from scores on exams to lengths of wings on bugs.

name: Rational functions
description: Just as the polynomials are analogous to the integers, rational functions are analogous to the rational numbers. We will learn more about this analogy as we rewrite various rational expressions, and also think about their graphical behavior.

name: Foundations
description: This topic isn't algebra, but it is a survey of all of the most important pre-algebra skills you need to really digest algebra.  These skills also tend to be pretty important in life in general!

name: Algebraic expressions
description: The core idea in algebra is using letters to represent relationships between numbers without specifying what those numbers are!

name: Linear equations and inequalities
description: We will now equate two algebraic expressions and think about how it might constrain what value the variables can take on.  The algebraic manipulation you learn here really is the heart of algebra.

name: Graphing lines and slope
description: Use the power of algebra to understand and interpret points and lines (something we typically do in geometry).  This will include slope and the equation of a line.

name: Systems of equations
description: Solving a system of equations or inequalities in two variables by elimination, substitution, and graphing.

name: Expressions with exponents
description: Let's build our toolkit that allow us to manipulate exponents algebraically.

name: Quadratics and polynomials
description: We'll now progress beyond the world of purely linear expressions and equations and enter the world of quadratics (and more generally polynomials).  Learn to factor expressions that have powers of 2 in them and solve quadratic equations.  We'll also learn to manipulate more general polynomial expressions.

name: Equations and geometry
description: See how algebra can be useful when solving geometrical problems.

name: Right triangles & trigonometry
description: Can you find the length of a missing side of a right triangle? You most likely can: if you are given two side lengths you can use the Pythagorean Theorem to find the third one. But, what if you are only given one side? Impossible? Cue sine, cosine, and tangent, which will help you solve for any side or any angle of a right traingle.

name: Trigonometric functions
description: Discover how to measure angles, distances, and heights using trigonometric ratios and the unit circle. Learn how to use sine, cosine, and tangent to solve real-world problems involving triangles and circular motion.

name: Non-right triangles & trigonometry
description: Trigonometric ratios are not only useful for right triangles, but also for any other kind of triangle. In this unit, you will discover how to apply the sine, cosine, and tangent ratios, along with the laws of sines and cosines, to find all of the side lengths and all of the angle measures in any triangle with confidence.

name: Trigonometric equations and identities
description: In this unit, you'll explore the power and beauty of trigonometric equations and identities, which allow you to express and relate different aspects of triangles, circles, and waves. You'll learn how to use trigonometric functions, their inverses, and various identities to solve and check equations and inequalities, and to model and analyze problems involving periodic motion, sound, light, and more.

name: Composite and inverse functions
description: We can compose functions by making the output of one function the input of another one. This simple-yet-rich idea opens up a world of fascinating applications. Inverse functions undo each other when we compose them.

name: Trigonometry
description: Knowing trig identities is one thing, but being able to prove them takes us to another level. In this unit, we'll prove various trigonometric identities and define inverse trigonometric functions, which allow us to solve trigonometric equations.

name: Complex numbers
description: Let's build off of our previous work with complex numbers and perform more sophisticated operations, like division. We'll also learn about a different and more visual way to represent complex numbers—polar form.

name: Rational functions
description: Divide one polynomial by another, and what do you get? A rational function! We'll analyze the family of rational functions, and we'll see some examples of how they can be useful in modeling contexts.

name: Conic sections
description: When we slice a cone, the cross-sections can look like a circle, ellipse, parabola, or a hyperbola. These are called conic sections, and they can be used to model the behavior of chemical reactions, electrical circuits, and planetary motion.

name: Vectors
description: Learn what vectors are and how they can be used to model real-world situations. Perform various operations with vectors like adding, subtracting, scaling, and conversion between rectangular to polar coordinates.

name: Matrices
description: Learn what matrices are and about their various uses: solving systems of equations, transforming shapes and vectors, and representing real-world situations. Learn how to add, subtract, and multiply matrices, and find the inverses of matrices.

name: Probability and combinatorics
description: Probability and combinatorics are the conceptual framework on which the world of statistics is built. Besides this important role, they are fascinating, fun, and often surprising!

name: Series
description: This unit explores geometric series, which involve multiplying by a common ratio, as well as arithmetic series, which add a common difference each time. We'll get to know summation notation, a handy way of writing out sums in a condensed form. Lastly, we'll learn the binomial theorem, a powerful tool for expanding expressions with exponents.

name: Limits and continuity
description: In this unit, we'll explore the concepts of limits and continuity. We'll start by learning the notation used to express limits, and then we'll practice estimating limits from graphs and tables. We'll also work on determining limits algebraically. From there, we'll move on to understanding continuity and discontinuity, and how the intermediate value theorem can help us reason about functions in these contexts.

name: Displaying a single quantitative variable
description: This unit covers some basic methods for graphing distributions of quantitative data like dot plots, histograms, and stem and leaf plots. We'll also explore how to use those displays to compare the features of different distributions.

name: Analyzing a single quantitative variable
description: This unit covers common measures of center like mean and median. We'll also learn to measure spread or variability with standard deviation and interquartile range, and use these ideas to determine what data can be considered an outlier.

name: Two-way tables
description: This unit covers methods for dealing with data that falls into categories. Learn how to use bar graphs, Venn diagrams, and two-way tables to see patterns and relationships in categorical data.

name: Scatterplots
description: We use scatter plots to explore the relationship between two quantitative variables, and we use regression to model the relationship and make predictions. This unit explores linear regression and how to assess the strength of linear models.

name: Study design
description: Statistics is all about forming questions and gathering data to explore those questions. This unit connects these questions to aspects of research design, including sampling and survey methods, observational studies, and basic experiment design.

name: Probability
description: If you're curious about the mathematical ins and outs of probability, you've come to the right unit! Here, we'll take a deep dive into the many ways we can calculate the likelihood of different outcomes. From using simulations to the addition and multiplication rules, we'll build a solid foundation that will help us tackle statistical questions down the line.

name: Probability distributions & expected value
description: A random variable is some outcome from a chance process, like how many heads will occur in a series of 20 flips, or how many seconds it took someone to read this sentence. Calculate probabilities and expected value of random variables, and look at ways to ransform and combine random variables.

name: Analyzing categorical data
description: If you're grouping things by anything other than numerical values, you're grouping them by categories. By learning how to use tools such as bar graphs, Venn diagrams, and two-way tables, you'll expand your abilities to see patterns and relationships in categorical data.

name: Displaying and comparing quantitative data
description: Can you measure it with numbers? Then it's quantitative data! This unit covers some basic methods for graphing distributions of quantitative data like dot plots, histograms, and stem and leaf plots. We'll also explore how to use those displays to compare the features of different distributions.

name: Summarizing quantitative data
description: This unit covers common measures of center like mean and median. We'll also learn to measure spread or variability with standard deviation and interquartile range, and use these ideas to determine what data can be considered an outlier.

name: Modeling data distributions
description: This unit takes our understanding of distributions to the next level. We'll measure the position of data within a distribution using percentiles and z-scores, we'll learn what happens when we transform data, we'll study how to model distributions with density curves, and we'll look at one of the most important families of distributions called Normal distributions.

name: Exploring bivariate numerical data
description: Scatter plots are a handy tool that allow us examine how two sets of quantitative data are—or aren't—correlated with one another. Learn how to set up a scatter plot, and how to measure the degree of correlation between two data sets through the process of linear regression.

name: Study design
description: Every good investigation begins with a good question! Learn how to form questions and gather data to explore those questions. You'll also learn about some investigative techniques, including sampling, survey methods, observational studies, and basic experimental design.

name: Probability
description: Probability tells us how often some event will happen after many repeated trials. You've experienced probability when you've flipped a coin, rolled some dice, or looked at a weather forecast. Go deeper with your understanding of probability as you learn about theoretical, experimental, and compound probability, and investigate permutations, combinations, and more!

name: Counting, permutations, and combinations
description: How many outfits can you make from the shirts, pants, and socks in your closet? Address this question and more as you explore methods for counting how many possible outcomes there are in various situations. Learn about factorial, permutations, and combinations, and look at how to use these ideas to find probabilities.

name: Random variables
description: Random variables can be any outcomes from some chance process, like how many heads will occur in a series of 20 flips of a coin. We calculate probabilities of random variables and calculate expected value for different types of random variables.

name: Sampling distributions
description: If I take a sample, I don't always get the same results. However, sampling distributions—ways to show every possible result if you're taking a sample—help us to identify the different results we can get from repeated sampling, which helps us understand and use repeated samples. Explore some examples of sampling distribution in this unit!

name: Confidence intervals
description: "The average lifespan of a fruit fly is between 1 day and 10 years" is an example of a confidence interval, but it's not a very useful one. From scientific measures to election predictions, confidence intervals give us a range of plausible values for some unknown value based on results from a sample. Let's learn to make useful and reliable confidence intervals for means and proportions.

name: Significance tests (hypothesis testing)
description: Significance tests give us a formal process for using sample data to evaluate the likelihood of some claim about a population value. Learn how to conduct significance tests and calculate p-values to see how likely a sample result is to occur by random chance. You'll also see how we use p-values to make conclusions about hypotheses.

name: Two-sample inference for the difference between groups
description: Learn how to apply what you know about confidence intervals and significance tests to situations that involve comparing two samples to see if there is a significant difference between the two populations.

name: Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests)
description: Chi-square tests are a family of significance tests that give us ways to test hypotheses about distributions of categorical data. This topic covers goodness-of-fit tests to see if sample data fits a hypothesized distribution, and tests for independence between two categorical variables.

name: Advanced regression (inference and transforming)
description: Go beyond linear as you explore the concept of advanced regression. Advanced regression will introduce you to regression methods when there's a non-linear pattern of correlation between data.

name: Analysis of variance (ANOVA)
description: Analysis of variance, or ANOVA, is an approach to comparing data with multiple means across different groups, and allows us to see patterns and trends within complex and varied data. See three examples of ANOVA in action as you learn how it can be applied to more complex statistical analyses.

name: Linear equations and inequalities
description: Linear equations and inequalities are the foundation of many advanced math topics, such as functions, systems, matrices, and calculus. Learn how to master them and unlock new possibilities for your future studies and careers in engineering, finance, computer science, and more.

name: Graphs and forms of linear equations
description: Part of the beauty of linear equations is that we can write them in different (but equivalent!) ways to highlight different features. Whether we want a particular point, an intercept, or the slope of the line to be most prominent, there's an equation form that shows it off.

name: Functions
description: A function is like a machine that takes an input and gives an output. Let's explore how we can graph, analyze, and create different types of functions.

name: Quadratics: Multiplying and factoring
description: Let's dive into the world of binomials and quadratics. Exponents are the place value of algebraic expressions. We'll multiply and factor these algebraic expressions, and discover some special patterns that make certain problems a breeze.

name: Quadratic functions and equations
description: Want to know the path a soccer ball will take through the air? We need quadratic equations. Some equation-solving strategies, like taking the square root or factoring, work best with friendly numbers. Others, like completing the square, work with any kind of numbers. Which will you choose?

name: Complex numbers
description: Humans expand our number system when we find new questions to answer. For finding distances in construction, we opened up to irrational numbers. For solutions for more quadratics, we unveiled complex numbers. The good news is, complex numbers follow most of the same patterns as the numbers that came before.

name: Exponents and radicals
description: If we follow the patterns from our whole number exponents, we can discover how negative exponents will behave. Exponents wouldn't be complete without their (almost) inverse operation, taking roots. Finally, we'll use exponents to represent quantities that are changing proportionally to their size at any given time.

name: Rational expressions and equations
description: Rational expressions bring together what we know from fractions with our polynomial skills. They arise in a variety of contexts involving rates, particularly when there are unknowns or changing values in the denominator. We'll model with basic rational expressions, then use the polynomial properties to extend our fraction operations.

name: Relating algebra and geometry
description: Let's explore how geometry and algebra intersect. Did you think the Pythagorean theorem was just for triangles? It shows up all over the place, like in the equation for a circle or in the distance between two points. We'll also learn how slope relates to parallel and perpendicular lines.

name: Polynomial arithmetic
description: We can add, subtract, multiply, and factor with polynomials like we do with numbers. The exponents show us the place value for the variables, so that we can add like to like. We'll find the average rate of change (closely related to slope) of polynomials, too.

name: Advanced function types
description: Let's use the building blocks of simpler function types to explore functions that zig-zag or twist across the screen. Come explore the weird and wonderful world of absolute value graphs, piecewise functions, and inverses! Build chains of functions by composing them, feeding the output from one function into another!

name: Transformations of functions
description: Once we know a handful of parent functions, we can transform those functions to build related functions. Geometry swoops in as we translate, reflect, and dilate the graphs, working back and forth between the geometric and algebraic forms.

name: Rational exponents and radicals
description: Did you know that square and cube roots are a kind of exponent? They're just so common, they get a special symbol. Now, we'll be able to use the exponent properties to simplify expressions whether they have exponent or radical symbols.

name: Logarithms
description: You've seen inverse operations like multiplication and division. Because powers are not commutative, it takes two operations to undo them. Radicals let us work backwards to get a base, but logarithms retrieve the exponent. The logarithmic properties may look new, but they're just the exponential properties in a new notation.

name: Limits and continuity
description: Limits describe the behavior of a function as we approach a certain input value, regardless of the function's actual value there. Continuity requires that the behavior of a function around a point matches the function's value at that point. These simple yet powerful ideas play a major role in all of calculus.

name: Differentiation: definition and basic derivative rules
description: The derivative of a function describes the function's instantaneous rate of change at a certain point - it gives us the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point. See how we define the derivative using limits, and learn to find derivatives quickly with the very useful power, product, and quotient rules.

name: Differentiation: composite, implicit, and inverse functions
description: The chain rule tells us how to find the derivative of a composite function. This is an exceptionally useful rule, as it opens up a whole world of functions (and equations!) we can now differentiate. Also learn how to use all the different derivative rules together in a thoughtful and strategic manner.

name: Contextual applications of differentiation
description: Derivatives describe the rate of change of quantities. This comes in handy when solving various problems that are related to rates of change in applied, real-world, situations. You'll also learn how to apply derivatives to approximate function values and find limits using L’Hôpital’s rule.

name: Applying derivatives to analyze functions
description: The first and the second derivative of a function give us all sorts of useful information about that function's behavior. The first derivative tells us where a function increases or decreases or has a maximum or minimum value; the second derivative tells us where a function is concave up or down and where it has inflection points.

name: Integration and accumulation of change
description: The definite integral is an important tool in calculus. It calculates the area under a curve, or the accumulation of a quantity over time. Riemann sums allow us to approximate integrals, while the fundamental theorem of calculus reveals how they connect to derivatives.

name: Differential equations
description: Differential equations are equations that include both a function and its derivative (or higher-order derivatives). For example, y=y' is a differential equation. Learn how to find and represent solutions of basic differential equations.

name: Applications of integration
description: Definite integrals are all about the accumulation of quantities. Let's see how they are applied in order to solve various kinds of problems.

description: Watch as Sal solves free response questions from past AP Calculus exams. This is a good preparation for your upcoming exam!

name: AP®︎ Calculus AB Standards mappings
description: Dig into the world of AP®︎ Calculus AB and find out how our free course material aligns with the standards set by the College Board.

name: Applications of integration

name: Parametric equations, polar coordinates, and vector-valued functions
description: While we're often familiar with functions that output just one variable and are graphed with Cartesian coordinates, there are other possibilities! Vector-valued functions, for example, can output multiple variables. Polar functions, too, differ, using polar coordinates for graphing. We can still explore these functions with derivatives and integrals.

name: Infinite sequences and series
description: Series are sums of multiple terms. Infinite series are sums of an infinite number of terms. Don't all infinite series grow to infinity? It turns out the answer is no. Some infinite series converge to a finite value. Learn how this is possible, how we can tell whether a series converges, and how we can explore convergence in Taylor and Maclaurin series.

description: Watch as Sal solves free response questions from past AP Calculus exams. This is a good preparation for your upcoming exam!

description: Dig into the world of AP®︎ Calculus BC and find out how our free course material aligns with the standards set by the College Board.

name: Exploring categorical data
description: This unit covers methods for dealing with data that falls into categories. Learn how to use bar graphs, Venn diagrams, and two-way tables to see patterns and relationships in categorical data.

name: Exploring one-variable quantitative data: Displaying and describing
description: This unit covers some basic methods for graphing distributions of quantitative data like dot plots, histograms, and stem and leaf plots. We'll also explore how to use those displays to compare the features of different distributions.

name: Exploring one-variable quantitative data: Summary statistics
description: This unit covers common measures of center like mean and median. We'll also learn to measure spread or variability with standard deviation and interquartile range, and use these ideas to determine what data can be considered an outlier.

name: Exploring one-variable quantitative data: Percentiles, z-scores, and the normal distribution
description: This unit takes our understanding of distributions to the next level. We'll measure the position of data within a distribution using percentiles and z-scores, we'll learn what happens when we transform data, we'll study how to model distributions with density curves, and we'll look at one of the most important families of distributions called Normal distributions.

name: Exploring two-variable quantitative data
description: We use scatter plots to explore the relationship between two quantitative variables, and we use regression to model the relationship and make predictions. This unit explores linear regression and how to assess the strength of linear models.

name: Collecting data
description: Statistics is all about forming questions and gathering data to explore those questions. This unit connects these questions to aspects of research design, including sampling and survey methods, observational studies, and basic experiment design.

name: Probability
description: If you're curious about the mathematical ins and outs of probability, you've come to the right unit! Here, we'll take a deep dive into the many ways we can calculate the likelihood of different outcomes. From using simulations to the addition and multiplication rules, we'll build a solid foundation that will help us tackle statistical questions down the line.

name: Random variables and probability distributions
description: A random variable is some outcome from a chance process, like how many heads will occur in a series of 20 flips, or how many seconds it took someone to read this sentence. Calculate probabilities and expected value of random variables, and look at ways to ransform and combine random variables.

name: Sampling distributions
description: A sampling distribution shows every possible result a statistic can take in every possible sample from a population and how often each result happens - and can help us use samples to make predictions about the chance tht something will occur. This unit covers how sample proportions and sample means behave in repeated samples.

name: Inference for categorical data: Proportions
description: How many people do you have to poll to have a 90% confidence in the outcome of an upcoming election? This unit, which covers confidence intervals and significance tests for proportions of populations, will show you how to do just that.

name: Inference for quantitative data: Means
description: From quality control to predicting the amount of snowfall that will result from an upcoming blizzard, this unit will give you the tools to calculate an inference from a population mean to make predictions about quantitative outcomes.

name: Inference for categorical data: Chi-square
description: Learn to test how well sample counts of a categorical variable fit some hypothesized distribution, or, if the distribution of a categorical variable is similar or not across multiple groups.

name: Inference for quantitative data: slopes
description: Learn how to perform inference on slope in least-squares regression. We'll make confidence intervals and do significance tests to see if a linear relationship in a sample suggests a relationship exists in the corresponding population.

name: Prepare for the 2022 AP®︎ Statistics Exam
description: Check out some examples of worked free-response items from previous exams, and practice choosing an appropriate inference procedure given a scenario.

name: Thinking about multivariable functions
description: The only thing separating multivariable calculus from ordinary calculus is this newfangled word "multivariable". It means we'll deal with functions whose inputs or outputs live in two or more dimensions. Here, we lay the foundations for thinking about and visualizing multivariable functions.

name: Derivatives of multivariable functions
description: What does it mean to take the derivative of a function whose input lives in multiple dimensions? What about when its output is a vector? Here we go over many different ways to  extend the idea of a derivative to higher dimensions, including partial derivatives​, directional derivatives, the gradient, vector derivatives, divergence, curl, and more!

name: Applications of multivariable derivatives
description: The tools of partial derivatives, like the gradient and other concepts, can be used to optimize and approximate multivariable functions. These are very useful in the real world—this is one of the main reasons why people study multivariable calculus!

name: Integrating multivariable functions
description: There are many ways to extend the idea of integration to multiple dimensions: some examples include Line integrals, double integrals, triple integrals, and surface integrals. Each one lets you add infinitely many infinitely small values, where those values might come from points on a curve, points in an area, or points on a surface. These are all very powerful tools, relevant to almost all real-world applications of calculus, especially in physics.

name: Green's, Stokes', and the divergence theorems
description: Here we cover four different ways to extend the fundamental theorem of calculus to multiple dimensions. Green's theorem and the 2D divergence theorem do this for two dimensions, then we crank it up to three dimensions with Stokes' theorem and the (3D) divergence theorem.

name: First order differential equations
description: Differential equations relate a function to its derivative. That means the solution set is one or more functions, not a value or set of values. Lots of phenomena change based on their current value, including population sizes, the balance remaining on a loan, and the temperature of a cooling object.

name: Second order linear equations
description: In second order linear equations, the equations include second derivatives. They are useful for modeling the movement of bridges, the transfer of heat, and even the behavior of subatomic particles. From understanding the basics to tackling complex roots and the method of undetermined coefficients, come master these versatile equations.

name: Laplace transform
description: The Laplace transform is a mathematical technique that changes a function of time into a function in the frequency domain. If we transform both sides of a differential equation, the resulting equation is often something we can solve with algebraic methods.

name: Vectors and spaces
description: Vectors are used to represent many things around us: from forces like gravity, acceleration, friction, stress and strain on structures, to computer graphics used in almost all modern-day movies and video games. Vectors are an important concept, not just in math, but in physics, engineering, and computer graphics, so you're likely to see them again in other subjects.

name: Matrix transformations
description: Matrices can be used to perform a wide variety of transformations on data, which makes them powerful tools in many real-world applications. For example, matrices are often used in computer graphics to rotate, scale, and translate images and vectors. They can also be used to solve equations that have multiple unknown variables (x, y, z, and more) and they do it very efficiently!

name: Alternate coordinate systems (bases)
description: What happens when we have multiple transformations that cannot be easily perfomed on a coordinate system? We get creative! By changing the coordinate systems to different bases we can turn overly-complicated transformations into much easier tasks.

name: Get ready for addition and subtraction
description: Let's build a solid foundation of place value, adding, and subtracting smaller numbers so that we'll be ready for adding and subtracting larger numbers in third grade. This unit will expand your addition and subtraction skills by working with numbers up to 1000 and using various visual tools to help you solve.

name: Get ready for multiplication and division
Get ready for fractions
description: Let's build a solid foundation of equal parts so that we'll be ready for fractions in third grade. From circles to rectangles, this unit will make you a whiz at identifying fractional parts.

name: Get ready for patterns and problem solving
description: Let's build a solid foundation of addition and subtraction word problems so that we'll be ready for patterns and problem solving in third grade. In this unit, you will tackle word problems from every angle—adding, subtracting, number lines, and even 2-step word problems!

name: Get ready for area and perimeter
description: Let's build a solid foundation of measurement and length so that we will be ready for area and perimeter in third grade. From identifying units of length in centimeter, meters, inches and feet, to measuring items in those length, we will cover it all.

name: Get ready for telling time
description: Let's build a solid foundation of the clock so that we can tell time in third grade. We will start by learning to tell time on the number line, and then switch gears and tell time on the clock. From telling time to the nearest half hour to the nearest 5 mins, this unit will prepare you for telling time to the nearest minute.

name: Get ready for data
description: Let's build a solid foundation of data so we can represent and interpret data in third grade. We will make bar graphs, picture graphs, and line plots and then take that knowledge and apply it to word problems.

name: Get ready for place value
description: Let's build a solid foundation of place value so we will be ready for writing numbers in different forms in fourth grade. We will work on identifying numbers within 1,000 and regrouping those whole numbers. All of this will get us ready for comparing, regrouping, and writing even largers numbers in fourth grade!

name: Get ready for addition, subtraction, and estimation
description: Let's build a solid foundation of numbers so we will be ready for addition, subtraction and estimation in fourth grade. We will round numbers, discover strategies for addition and subtraction, and practice those skills so we can accelerate our skills in fourth grade.

name: Get ready for multiplication
description: Let's build a solid foundation of multiplication so we will be ready to multipy 1 and 2-digit numbers in fourth grade! In this unit, we will practice using equal groups, number lines, groups of objects, and array to multipy. To wrap things up, we will use the associative property, distributive property, and commutitive property to better understand multiplication.

name: Get ready for division
description: Let's build a solid foundation of dividing within 100 so we can divide within 1,000 in fourth grade! Groups of objects, arrays, and visuals will helps us understand division so we can apply those skills to multi-digit division and other fourth grade strategies.

name: Get ready for fractions
description: Let's build a solid foundation of equal parts so that we'll be ready for fractions in third grade. From circles to rectangles, this unit will make you a whiz at identifying fractional parts.

name: Get ready for plane figures
description: In this unit, you'll get to dive into the fascinating world of quadrilaterals! You'll learn how to spot them, figure out what makes them unique, and even sort them into different categories. Whether you're a geometry whiz or just starting out, this unit is sure to be a fun and engaging adventure

name: Get ready for area and perimeter
description: Let's build a solid foundation of measurement and length so that we will be ready for area and perimeter in third grade. From identifying units of length in centimeter, meters, inches and feet, to measuring items in those length, we will cover it all.

name: Get ready for decimal place value
description: Get ready for a journey to help you understand the often tricky world of decimals. You'll learn all about how different digits can have different values, and how to compare decimals with ease.
