By the end of the unit, you'll be a master of rounding, writing, and comparing decimals like a pro!

name: Get ready for adding and subtracting decimals
description: This unit is all about flexing your adding and subtracting muscles! You'll learn some nifty strategies for working with numbers up to 1000, and practice multi-digit addition and subtraction too. By the end of the unit, you'll be ready to take on decimals like a pro. Get ready to crunch some numbers!

name: Get ready for adding and subtracting fractions
description: This fraction unit is jam-packed with everything you need to become a fraction master! From understanding equivalent fractions to adding and subtracting mixed numbers, you'll be able to tackle any fraction problem that comes your way. Get ready to dive in and take your math skills to the next level!

name: Get ready for multiplication and division with whole numbers and decimals
description: Ready to multiply and divide large numbers? In this unit, you'll learn different ways to solve multi-digit multiplication and division problems. You'll use area models, distributive property, regrouping, and place value to make your calculations easier and faster. You'll also practice dividing with remainders and by larger divisors. By the end of this unit, you'll be ready to tackle decimals.

name: Get ready for multiplying and dividing fractions
description: Get ready to multiply and divide fractions with confidence! You'll start by learning the basics of multiplication and division. You'll get to practice your skills with word problems and finding the area of rectangles. By the end, you'll be surprised at how much you've learned!

name: Get ready for powers of 10
description: Introducing... the power of 10! You'll get to explore how this nifty number relates to place value, and how it can help you understand decimal fractions. By the end of the unit, you'll be able to multiply and divide whole numbers by 10 like a pro. Get ready to get your math on!

name: Get ready for volume
description: Let's dive into the world of volume! You'll start by brushing up on your understanding of area because the two concepts are closely related. Then, you'll learn how to use unit squares to measure area in a super straightforward way. Lastly, you'll put your new skills to the test by comparing different areas. Let's get measuring!

name: Get ready for properties of shapes
description: It's time to get to know quadrilaterals. You'll learn how to tell them apart, figure out what makes them unique, and put them into categories. By the end of the unit, you'll be a quadrilateral expert--able to spot a square, rectangle, or rhombus from a mile away!

name: Get ready for ratios, rates, and percentages
description: Want to make twice as many cookies as the recipe calls for? Then you'll need to double the recipe, which requires skills in ratios, rates, and percentages. Review multiplication, division, and graphing as you build up your ratio, rates, and percentages skills!

name: Get ready for arithmetic operations
description: Addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division - there's so much you can do with these arithmetic operations! Use your understanding of arithmetic to take one some more challenging problems, such dividing whole numbers by unit fractions or decimals, as you show your skills and get ready to tackle tougher problems!

name: Get ready for negative numbers
description: If you've mastered the world of positive numbers, hang on to your hats, because it's time to put negative numbers in the mix! Now you'll be able to explore fractions on the entire number line and graph points in all four quadrants of a coordinate plane. Get ready for a new challenge!

name: Get ready for equations, expressions, and inequalities
description: Get ready for an exciting exploration of expressions, equations, and inequalities! As you sharpen your understanding of factors, multiples, prime and composite numbers, and powers of 10, you'll feel more and more confident taking on new mathematical challenges.

name: Get ready for geometry
description: Let's take a tour through all sorts of important concepts in geometry, going from finding the area and perimeter of shapes to multiplying fractions and mixed numbers. Then, take your skills to another dimension as you figure out the volume of rectangular prisms and get ready to take on 6th grade math!

name: Get ready for negative number operations
description: Dive into the world of negative numbers! You'll learn how to locate them on a number line, and understand the concept of absolute value. You'll also review your skills in adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing fractions, leaving you positively prepared to go below zero.

name: Get ready for fractions, decimals, & percentages
description: You've learned the basics of fractions, decimals, and percentages,, so let's take these skills to the next level! Get ready to tackle some real-world word problems that will make you a master of these concepts.

name: Get ready for rates & proportional relationships
description: Let's explore how ratios and proportions can lead to relationships between two or more numbers. See how ratios can be applied in all sorts of ways--from cooking to graphing. By the end, you'll have a whole new understanding of how numbers and variables can relate to one another.

name: Get ready for expressions, equations, & inequalities
description: Get ready for adventures with expressions, equations, and inequalities! Put your distributive property skills to the test as you learn how to combine like terms and practice solving - and finding mistakes in - one-step equations. Finally, explore ways to identify possible values of a variable that's in an inequality.

name: Get ready for geometry
description: Let's take a tour through all sorts of important concepts in geometry, going from finding the area and perimeter of shapes to multiplying fractions and mixed numbers. Then, take your skills to another dimension as you figure out the volume of rectangular prisms and get ready to take on 6th grade math!

name: Get ready for statistics & probability
description: The world is full of data, and you have the power to make sense of it! Here, you'll learn how to ask good statistical questions, and strengthen your skills in identiying patterns in data by exploring features in different data distributions. Get ready to uncover all kinds of hidden information!

name: Get ready for numbers and operations
description: Let's get ready for the kinds of mathematical expressions you'll encounter in eighth grade! Sharpen your skills in converting fractions to decimals, multiplying and dividing decimals, and take your understanding of exponents to the next level as you begin to explore order of operations.

name: Get ready for solving equations and systems of equations
description: Time for a pre-algebraic adventure! Review your understanding of equations as you practice one-step equations with a variable, and take it to the next level by flexing your factoring muscles. Finally, you'll apply what you've learned to take on equations that require two steps to solve.

name: Get ready for linear equations and functions
description: Let's talk relationships - proportional relationships, that is! Investigate proportional relationships between numbers, see how these relationships can be represented through equations or graphs, and learn some nifty ways to apply proportionality to different aspects of our lives.

name: Get ready for geometry
description: Let's take a tour through all sorts of important concepts in geometry, going from finding the area and perimeter of shapes to multiplying fractions and mixed numbers. Then, take your skills to another dimension as you figure out the volume of rectangular prisms and get ready to take on 6th grade math!

name: Get ready for equations & inequalities
description: Tackle equations and inequalities with confidence! In this unit, we'll learn how to check your work, spot errors, and use key properties to simplify and solve problems.

name: Get ready for working with units
description: We can understand relationships between quantities by using ratios and rates. We'll learn how to compare, simplify, and apply these concepts to real-world scenarios from scaling recipes to dog walking.

name: Get ready for linear relationships
description: This unit is all about proportions. From learning how to identify the constant of proportionality to graphing and solving proportions, you'll be ready to apply your new knowledge to linear relationships.

name: Get ready for functions & sequences
description: Let's play with math patterns involving numbers, shapes, and variables before moving on to functions. We'll learn the basics, work with linear models, and experiment with both linear and nonlinear functions.

name: Get ready for exponents, radicals, & irrational numbers
description: This unit is all about expanding our skills with exponents and radicals (roots). We'll explore square and cube roots, learn about irrational numbers, and push ourselves to understand exponents with negative bases, exponent properties, and negative exponents.

name: Get ready for quadratics
description: In this unit, we'll dive into a variety of algebraic concepts that will help us when we learn about quadratics. We'll practice solving equations with square and cube roots, create equivalent expressions, and analyze graphs of functions.

name: Get ready for congruence, similarity, and triangle trigonometry
description: In this unit, we'll focus on understanding congruence and similarity, and how these concepts can be used to compare shapes. We'll also tackle the Pythagorean theorem and triangle trigonometry, so get ready to sharpen those pencils!

name: Get ready for analytic geometry
description: What do architects, graphic designers, and engineers all have in common? They use analytic geometry! In this unit of study, you'll learn the basics of using math to create precise drawings and models.

name: Get ready for conic sections
description: This unit lays the groundwork for understanding conic geometry. By covering basic concepts and definitions, it sets the stage for exploring the properties and applications of various shapes such as circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.

name: Get ready for circles and solid geometry
description: In this unit, we're circling back to one of the most fundamental shapes in geometry: the circle! We'll talk radius, diameter, circumference, and area, and even take a bite out of "pie" to get a full understanding.

name: Get ready for polynomial operations and complex numbers
description: Let's get ready for another algebraic adventure! Revisit your skills in operations involving polynomials as you review topics such as combining like terms and the distributive property and multiplication and division of powers and binomials. Finally, freshen up your factoring skills as you review some different factoring strategies.

name: Get ready for equations
description: Being an excellent solver of equations will set you up well for Algebra 2. Go over strategies for solving equations with variables on both sides, systems of equations, and quadratic equations. By the end of this unit, you'll feel confident tackling all sorts of mathematical expressions that include equal signs.

name: Get ready for transformations of functions and modeling with functions
description: Have some fun with functions! Review the basics of functions and explore some of the types of functions covered in earlier math courses, including absolute value functions and quadratic functions. You'll be in great shape to analyze and graph the more complex functions found in Algebra 2.

name: Get ready for exponential and logarithmic relationships
description: How is a graph of the function 2x different from a graph of the function x^2? Find out as you investigate the unique properties of exponential functions.

name: Get ready for trigonometry
description: Brush up on your trigonometry skills as you measure and calculate the sides, angles, and ratios of every kind of triangle. By triangulating your understanding of the Pythagorean theorem, coordinate planes, and angles, you'll be yet another degree prepared for Algebra 2.

name: Get ready for rational functions
description: Fractions, binomials, and quadratics, oh my! Reviewing these skills from earlier math courses will leave you prepared to analyze and calculate all sorts of mathematical expressions that involve numerators, denominators. and binomials.

name: Get ready for complex numbers
description: Imagine a number that can square itself and become negative. Sounds impossible, right? But it's not. Complex numbers let you find solutions that real numbers can't, and they help you understand and model many phenomena in nature, science, and art. In this unit, you'll learn how to create, manipulate, and visualize complex numbers, and how they relate to other areas of math.

name: Get ready for polynomials
description: Polynomials are powerful tools for precalculus, as they can represent complex patterns and functions. In this unit, you will master the skills of working with polynomials, such as finding zeros, dividing, and applying theorems. Engage with articles, activities, and videos that illustrate the relevance and beauty of polynomials.

name: Get ready for composite and inverse functions
description: How can you create new functions from existing ones? How can you undo a function and find its inverse? Discover the answers with interactive articles, activities, and videos that teach you about composite and inverse functions in precalculus and their applications in various fields.

name: Get ready for trigonometry
description: Brush up on your trigonometry skills as you measure and calculate the sides, angles, and ratios of every kind of triangle. By triangulating your understanding of the Pythagorean theorem, coordinate planes, and angles, you'll be yet another degree prepared for Algebra 2.

name: Get ready for vectors and matrices
description: Vectors and matrices are essential for modeling and solving problems in science, engineering, and art. Discover how to represent, operate, and visualize them using arrows, grids, and transformations. Read articles, watch videos, and do activities that introduce you to the concepts and applications of vectors and matrices.

name: Get ready for series
description: How do you add up infinitely many numbers? What patterns can you find in sequences of fractions, decimals, or powers? These articles, activities, and videos will get you practicing using formulas, notation, and graphs, and prepare you for working with sequences and series in precalculus and calculus.

name: Get ready for conic sections
description: This unit lays the groundwork for understanding conic geometry. By covering basic concepts and definitions, it sets the stage for exploring the properties and applications of various shapes such as circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.

name: Get ready for probability and combinatorics
description: How can you use dice, cards, and puzzles to explore chance and patterns? Learn the basics of probability and combinatorics in precalculus through engaging articles, activities, and videos that share the relevance and fun of these topics.

name: Get ready for limits and continuity
description: In calculus, you'll encounter continuous functions that approach—but never get to—a limit. Don't worry if these functions sound funky—after reviewing skills such as factoring and trigonometric ratios to analyze different kinds of functions, you'll feel continuously limitless in the kinds of functions you can tackle!

name: Get ready for differentiation: definition and basic derivative rules
description: What does it mean to derive something mathematically? Review your graphing and exponent skills as you prepare to use them to find a function's slope at any point.

name: Get ready for differentiation: composite, implicit, and inverse functions
description: Inverse? Composite? No problem! Get into a 1/x state of mind as we apply differentiation to complex functions, including inverse functions and composite functions.

name: Get ready for contextual applications of differentiation
description: Derivatives come in handy in all sorts of contexts. Get ready to apply your differentiaion skills to a plethora of real-life planning, engineering, and measurement problems, like volume or rates of change.

name: Get ready for applying derivatives to analyze functions
description: Derive and conquer as we apply differentiation to pull out information about the distinguishing features of a function. See how you can identify changes in a function's rate of change and identify its maximum and minimum points.

name: Get ready for integration and accumulation of change
description: Build on your understanding of quadratiics and polynomials as you begin to explore how these skills can help us find the amount of space under a function—that is, a function's integral.

name: Get ready for applications of integration
description: Bring your equation-solving and geometry skills to integration as you look at some ways that you can solve for area and volume. You'll be a whiz when it comes to two- and three-dimensional shapes!

name: Get ready for parametric equations, polar coordinates, and vector-valued functions (BC only)
description: From measuring the volume of a piece of pie to determining the forces acting on a satellite, measuring sectors and vectors brings calculus to the real world. Learn how to go beyond magnitude and add in some direction!

name: Get ready for infinite sequences and series (BC only)
description: Sequences and series—we know they repeat ... again and again. Here you'll investigate features of arithmetic and geometric sequences and series to the nth degree as you gear up for AP Calculus BC!

name: Get ready for exploring categorical data
description: Categorical data might seem like a mouthful, but this unit will make it all make sense. You'll learn how to organize data into different categories, compare and contrast them, and even draw some conclusions. Get ready to put your critical thinking skills to the test.

name: Get ready for exploring one-variable quantitative data
description: Data can tell us all kinds of interesting things, but first we need to make sense of it. That's where this unit on one-variable quantitative data comes in. You'll learn the techniques you need to collect and organize data, and then draw your own conclusions from it.

name: Get ready for exploring two-variable quantitative data
description: When it comes to data, two variables can be better than one. This unit on two-variable quantitative data will teach you how to compare and contrast two sets of data and find correlations and relationships you might have missed.

name: Get ready for probability
description: Ready for a crash course in probability? In this unit, we'll dive into the nitty-gritty of fractions, decimals, and percentages. We'll learn how to compare, add, and subtract these quantities, and use them to evaluate the likelihood of various events happening. Let's get started!

name: Get ready for random variables and probability distributions
description: Are you feeling lucky? In this unit, we'll learn how to use probability to make predictions. We'll explore the counting principle, which will help us understand how outcomes can be combined, and dive into the fascinating world of probability distributions. Let's get ready to roll the dice!

name: Fairy Tales Retold
description: How would you tell your own version of your favorite fairytale? There’s a lot we can learn about classic stories by writing different versions of them. What did the other characters think, and why was the villain bad? What if the story took place in a big city or in outer space? What happens after the characters live happily ever after?

name: The Moon
description: Have you ever looked up at the night sky and wondered about the moon? What is it like to visit? What is it made out of? People have been watching, learning, and writing about the moon for thousands of years. This unit answers some questions about the moon, and might get you to start asking your own questions, too.

name: Rural, Suburban, Urban
description: A community is a group of people all living in the same place. There are lots of different types of communities. Some have many people living close together close to places like shops, offices, hospitals, museums, movie theaters, and parks. Others have fewer people and buildings, but more nature and open space. Learn about how communities impact your life and how they can change over time.

name: Pets
description: Have you ever had a pet, or made friends with someone else’s pet? Pets can help people who are lonely or stressed. Different kinds of pets have different qualities, like size and personality. In this unit, we’ll be learning more about different kinds of pets and how we can help a person to choose a type of pet.

name: Homes
description: What comes to mind when you think of the word “house”? Is it the same as what you imagine when you think of the word “home”? In this unit, you will be learning all about different types of houses, and different ways that families come together to make those houses into homes.

name: Extreme Environments
description: Your environment means everything around you. The weather, the landscape, and the types of plants and animals that live there are all part of your environment. Some places on earth have extreme environments—places that are incredibly hot or cold, or that have intense storms. Learn how extreme environments affect the lives of people living there!

name: Superheroes
description: What does it mean to have a superpower, and what makes for a great superhero character and story? Learn about superheroes from different countries around the world, what powers they have, and who they battle against. You'll also read stories featuring some brand new superheroes, and think about how well current superheroes reflect the identities of all superhero fans.

name: Growth Mindset
description: Growth mindset is the belief that you can grow your brain and that your intelligence grows with effort and the right learning strategies. Learn about the secret superpowers of the human brain and how to exercise it like a muscle as you read about ways that people have used growth mindset to overcome difficult situations.

name: Journeys West
description: In the 19th century, many Americans in search of a better life migrated to the western half of North America. But these were Native American lands, and the mostly white settlers didn't ask for permission to pass through or live there. Learn about the history of the Americans who moved west, and the experiences of Native peoples who were affected  by this migration.

name: Imaginative Worlds
description: In this unit, we’ll read about some fictional worlds and see what we can learn from them. Can the characters’ struggles with villains and magic represent problems we face in real life? Can the heroes be role models for us? What do imaginary worlds have in common with our own world?

name: Athletes in Action
description: Female athletes and athletes of color often must overcome the prejudice and barriers that people put in their way—both within their sports, and in society in general. In this unit, you’ll learn about some of the people who’ve broken through those barriers and paved the way for future generations to follow in their footsteps.

name: Inventing Progress
description: The history of technology includes brilliant inventors and their world-changing inventions, and technological progress is a result of hard work, trial and error, and, sometimes, lucky accidents. But how does an inventor bring an idea to life and keep their ideas from being stolen? Learn about some inventors, their ideas, and how they have competed against or cooperated with one another.

name: Banning Behavior
description: Laws and rules ... without them, there would be chaos! But laws aren’t perfect, and they’re constantly being changed. Get ready to explore  how laws are made, and to look at some of the difficult decisions involved in making them. Finally, see how we can change rules that are outdated or unfair.

name: Identity
description: What makes us who we are? This is a fundamental, but difficult, question to answer. How can we become who we want to be? This unit examines these questions with stories about people, both real and fictional, who are exploring their identity.

name: Ocean Conservation
description: Nearly three-quarters of the earth is covered in water, and the oceans have all sorts of amazing ecosystems. But human actions, like using plastic and producing greenhouse gases, are endangering marine wildlife. This unit covers the impact humans have on the oceans and what we can do to help.

name: Trailblazing Women
description: In this unit, we’ll be learning about some women who have changed the world in big and small ways. We’ll learn what they accomplished, how they accomplished it, and how their work has made a difference to the world. How can learning about their experiences help us achieve our own dreams?

name: Mysteries of the Past
description: Travel back in time to late 16th century North America, when the the first major waves of white, European settlers migrated to the continent from countries like England. We’ll focus on the "lost” colony of Roanoke Island; a group of English immigrants who settled in modern-day North Carolina, but then vanished—and whose fate is still unknown today.

name: Living Tongues
description: Languages change over time and are influenced by culture, history, and technology. This causes new languages to evolve, and, sometimes, cause existing languages to become extinct. In this unit, you'll learn about endangered languages, explore he role languages play in society, and think about why people are making efforts to preserve languages.

name: Funny Business
description: Good jokes make us laugh. But what is it that makes them funny in the first place? In this unit, we’ll be learning about how comedy works. We'll also think about these questions: How is humor embedded in our culture? What are some different approaches to joke-making? Why is comedy valuable?

name: Obscuring the Truth
description: It’s always better to be honest, right? While lying often causes unnecessary problems, sometimes telling a lie can be useful and even the right thing to do! This unit examines the science of  how lying works and includes stories that demonstrate the good and bad that can come from fibbing.

name: Crossing the Line
description: What kinds of advantages are fair or unfair for professional athletes? In this unit, you'll look at how factors including genetic traits, training, and performance enhancing substances can impact athletic performance. You'll also examine controversies surrounding performance-enhancing drugs in athletics as you consider whether or not these substances should be allowed in athletic competitions.

name: Borders
description: Borders, both literal and metaphorical, have always played a role in our society. They can be helpful or cause harm, and, in this unit, we’ll explore their effects—both good and bad. In this unit, you will learn about borders that have impacted history, read people’s viewpoints about borders, and consider their effects on society.

name: Social Psychology
description: Oppression and other harmful behaviors show up throughout history. What motivates people to carry out acts of harm against others? How do oppressive and authoritarian societies come about in the first place; why do their members participate in the oppression; and how do they justify those acts of oppression to themselves? These are the questions we'll be digging into in this unit.

name: The Apocalypse
description: There are countless stories and movies about the end of the world.These stories can remind us of what we may take for granted, or can warn us of what might happen if we don't change our behavior. In this unit, you will read fiction, learn about representations of the apocalypse in film and literature, and think about common themes and characteristics of these stories.

name: Parts of speech: the noun
description: Here's the thing: I love nouns. But wait! Nouns aren't just things! They can also be people and places. They're my favorite parts of speech. Without them, we'd never be able to talk about *anything*!

name: Parts of speech: the verb
description: Oh no! What shall we DO? Great question, and one that a verb can answer! The verb is the part of speech that describes ACTIONS.

name: Parts of speech: the pronoun
description:
That mysterious man at the top of the stairs... *who* is *he*? The secretive lady who lives down the block... *what's* *she* up to? Those people in the purple cloaks... *why* are *they* so stylish?

No idea, to be honest. But PRONOUNS can at least help us figure out who they are!

name: Parts of speech: the modifier
description: Let's get descriptive! Modifiers, like adjectives and adverbs, describe nouns and verbs. If you understand modifiers, you can learn to express yourself elegantly.

name: Parts of speech: the preposition and the conjunction
description: Prepositions (in, out, before, after, with, without, just to name a few) help establish relationships in time, space, and among people and things. Conjunctions unite words; they attach phrases and clauses to one another.  They're super useful! Learn more about these two parts of speech here.

name: Punctuation: the comma and the apostrophe
description: Commas are the superheroes of punctuation! They can perform many different functions. Apostrophes are most often used to stand in for missing letters or to show possession. In the rarest of cases, they can be used to form plurals. Let's learn more!

name: Punctuation: the colon, semicolon, and more
description: Colons and semicolons are two valuable pieces of punctuation that separate sentence elements from each other. Learn more about how to use them here!

name: Syntax: sentences and clauses
description: Syntax involves arranging words to create logical phrases, clauses, and sentences. This is a big topic, so we'll be covering a lot, including: dependent and independent clauses; simple, complex, compound, and compound-complex sentences; and phrases and clauses.

name: Syntax: conventions of standard English
description: Syntax involves arranging words to create logical phrases, clauses, and sentences. This is a big topic, so we'll be covering a lot, including: subject-verb agreement, fragments, run-ons, and parallel structure.

name: Usage and style
description: This is where we'll talk about the conventions of Standard American English that aren't exactly about grammar, but about STYLE.  Harness the power of the sound of language; untangle frequently-confused words and expressions; and learn about why you probably shouldn't wear a tuxedo to a beach party.

name: Online data security
description: Let's surf safely! Become familiar with the concept of personal identifiable information (PII) and the ways in which PII can be tracked online. Learn how attackers can gain access to data and devices, and what steps you can take to shut down cybercriminals and keep your data and devices secure.

name: Welcome to Financial Literacy
description: Financial literacy is one of the most important skills you can develop in your life, but it can often be daunting and overwhelming. That's why we're thrilled to offer this course, which breaks everything down into manageable, easy-to-understand topics. We look forward to helping you take control of your financial future!

name: Budgeting and saving
description: Whether you're looking to pay off debt, save for a rainy day, or just feel more in control of your money, this unit on budgeting and saving money can help. With easy-to-follow instructions and practical tips, you'll learn the skills you need to take charge of your finances.

name: Consumer credit
description: Understanding credit is essential for making smart financial decisions. In this unit, you'll learn all about credit scores, credit reports, credit cards, and payment methods, so you can use credit to your advantage.

name: Additional resources
description: This unit is packed with valuable resources from our Personal Finance course. Here, you'll find articles and videos specifically curated to help you improve your financial literacy.

name: Saving and budgeting
description: What are your financial priorities? In this unit, Sal shares some basic strategies for creating a budget and saving money each month.

name: Interest and debt
description: How is interest calculated? What factors influence your credit score? What is the impact of only paying the minimum balance on your credit card? Build your knowledge of these key financial topics.

name: Investments and retirement
description: Financial security doesn't come from luck—it comes from knowledge and preparation. In this unit, you'll learn about different ways to invest your money and save for retirement, from the stock market to employer-based plans. Engaging videos and articles will make the complex simple.

name: Income and benefits
description: Why is your paycheck smaller than you expected? What are all those deductions? Learn about the factors that impact your take home pay.

name: Housing
description: Where you choose to live is both a personal and a financial decision. Should you rent or buy? How does your credit score impact your interest rate for a loan? And what exactly is escrow? Explore these topics to make an informed financial decision about the place you call home.

name: Car expenses
description: This unit will help you make the best decision when it comes to getting a new car. From weighing the pros and cons of buying or leasing, to crunching the numbers and understanding your finances, you'll be well-equipped to make an informed choice.

name: Taxes
description: Filing taxes can seem daunting, but this unit makes it easy to understand. With informative articles and engaging videos, you'll learn all about the US tax system, deductions, and common forms so you can file with confidence.

name: Paying for college
description: Getting into the college of your dreams is nice, but figuring out how to afford attending that college is even better!  Learn how to navigate the financial aid process with guidance on everything from filling out the FAFSA to identifying high priority scholarships.

name: Keeping your information safe
description: Protecting your personal information is crucial in today's digital age. This unit provides in-depth articles and videos that will teach you the best strategies for keeping your data safe and avoiding the devastating consequences of identity theft.

name: Getting started
description: Thinking about a 4-year college but not sure whether it's right for you?  This is the place to start!  Learn more about what happens during college, why it matters for your future, and the wide range of students who have chosen to attend.

name: Making high school count
description: Whether you're just entering 9th grade or in the thick of your junior year, it's never too early to begin thinking about college.  Find out how your academic record, extracurricular activities, and standardized test results impact the college admissions process.

name: Exploring college options
description: There are nearly 3,000 colleges in the United States that offer 4-year degrees.  The sheer variety of options, from rural liberal arts colleges to public state universities, can feel overwhelming.  After you understand the differences between what's out there and begin to get a sense of what you want, however, the choice becomes infinitely more manageable!

name: Applying to college
description: Once you've decided on several target schools, it's time to put together the all-important college application!  Prepare yourself for success with guidance from experts on topics such as admissions essays, letters of recommendation, and alumni interviews.

name: Paying for college
description: Getting into the college of your dreams is nice, but figuring out how to afford attending that college is even better!  Learn how to navigate the financial aid process with guidance on everything from filling out the FAFSA to identifying high priority scholarships.

name: Wrapping up
description: There is nothing more exciting than making the final decision on which college to attend.  It takes hard work to get to this point, but you've made it.  Now sit back, breathe a sigh of relief, and then learn a bit more about what comes next!

name: Life after college
description: Thinking about what to do next? We're developing a new series to answer tough questions about your career and your finances.

name: Navigate your career
description: Are you wondering how to land your dream job or negotiate your salary? We ask real people in real jobs how they make it all work in our video series about careers. In addition, explore articles and videos that will help you land a job and make strong financial decisions.

name: Serve your community
description: Are you driven to help others? These careers enable you to give back to your community through public service, missions work, or emergency response.

name: Support health and wellness
description: Whether you're interested in direct interaction with patients or working behind the scenes to improve systems, the healthcare field provides several avenues to support wellness.

name: Work in tech
description: The tech field is vast and growing with several avenues to explore, from engineering to design to business management.

name: Advertise and sell
description: These careers put your sales skills to the test. They require strong communication and drive. (More careers will be added soon.)

name: Start a business or go freelance
description: Thinking about starting your own business? Learn from the experiences of young professionals who have gone into business for themselves.

name: Educate
description: Explore careers that involve teaching others, both inside and outside of a classroom environment.

name: Explore hospitality
description: The hospitality industry encompasses many roles, from preparing delicious foods to ensuring that guests to your town have a great stay. If you're a people-person, a job in hospitality may be for you.

name: Design, create, perform
description: Is creativity a driving force in your life? These careers encourage creative expression.

name: Conduct research
description: Do you love to investigate new things? That interest can serve you well in your career. Independent inquiry is a key element of these professions.

name: Build and fix things
description: These careers require precision and problem-solving to build reliable structures and systems.

name: Manage people and processes
description: Help organizations run more efficiently by developing procedures and supporting teams of people.

name: Pursue criminal justice
description: These roles require ongoing training and the ability to cope with complex, and often negative, situations to uphold justice. The criminal justice field is broad - these roles represent of a few of many paths.

name: Analyze and advise
description: These roles involve both extensive research and client interaction. They also require the confidence to provide high stakes business and financial advice.

name: Travel and explore
description: These careers will put your navigation skills to the test, while allowing you to explore new environments. They're not your typical 9-5 job.

name: Growth mindset introduction for teachers
description: Dave Paunesku is the Executive Director of Stanford University's Project for Education Research That Scales (PERTS). In these videos, he explains what a growth mindset is, why it's so important to foster in our students, and how to encourage it in all of our classes.

name: High school activities
description: Learn about how to train your brains to be more resilient and flexible! In this unit, you'll find articles and videos packed with ideas and suggestions about how to encourage and cultivate a growth mindset throughout your life.

name: Elementary and middle school activities
description: Understanding your brain is key to learning and growth. Through articles, activities, and videos, this unit provides engaging ideas to learn more about the growth mindset, setting goals, and overcoming frustration - empowering you to develop the skills you need to succeed.

name: Cells and organisms
description: This unit is your ticket to a fascinating journey through the world of cells and organisms. You'll get an up-close look at plant and animal cells, learn all about organelles, explore the organization of the human body, and gain a deeper understanding of sensory processing and the brain.

name: Organism growth and reproduction
description: Let's learn how organisms grow and make more of themselves! Whether it's through sexual or asexual reproduction, there's a lot to learn about what makes for success, and how genes and the environment come into play.

name: Matter and energy in organisms
description: In this unit, you'll learn the basics of photosynthesis, cellular respiration, and biomolecules. You'll learn about the chemical processes that make life possible, and you might just come away with a new appreciation for the complexity of the natural world!

name: Interactions in ecosystems
description: Ecosystems are intricate webs of life that provide us with essential goods and services. In this unit, you'll learn about how ecosystems adapt and bounce back from changes, as well as how human activities can impact them in both positive and negative ways.

name: Matter and energy in ecosystems
description: In this unit, you'll learn all about the way populations grow, the limits to their growth, and the way energy and matter move in ecosystems. You'll also explore the carbon cycle, a crucial process that keeps our planet in balance.

name: Ecosystems and biodiversity
description: Why is biodiversity is so important? In this unit, you'll explore ecosystem dynamics and learn about the benefits humans get from healthy and diverse ecosystems.

name: Inheritance and variation
description: Ready to learn about the blueprints of life? In this unit, we'll explore the basics of genetics, from how genes are expressed to how they're shuffled during meiosis. We'll also examine the incredible ways that both our genes and our environment can influence our traits and shape who we are.

name: Evolution
description: This unit explores evolution. Learn about evolution and common ancestry, the fossil record, and anatomical and embryological evidence of evolution.

name: Natural and artificial selection
description: In this unit, you'll learn all about the fascinating processes of natural and artificial selection. Discover the key roles that adaptation and environmental change play in shaping how species evolve over time.

name: Earth in space
course: Middle school Earth and space science - NGSS
description: Ready to blast off into the far reaches of the universe? In this unit, you'll learn all about Earth's place in the cosmos, explore the mysteries of galaxies and gravity, and take a grand tour of our very own solar system.

name: The Earth-sun-moon system
course: Middle school Earth and space science - NGSS
description: In this unit, you'll explore the inner workings of the Earth-sun-moon system. Discover the secrets of our seasons, learn why the moon waxes and wanes, and find out what causes the stunning spectacle of a solar eclipse.

name: Weather and climate
course: Middle school Earth and space science - NGSS
description: We might not be able to control the weather, but we can definitely understand it. With lessons on the water cycle, weather systems, global winds and currents, and regional climates, this unit will help you make sense of the forecast.

name: The geosphere
course: Middle school Earth and space science - NGSS
description: Rock on with this unit all about the geosphere! From the rock cycle to weathering and erosion, you'll explore the gritty details of our planet's foundation.

name: Earth and society
course: Middle school Earth and space science - NGSS
description: Earth provides us with so much: resources, beauty, and a home. But our relationship isn't always smooth sailing. From natural hazards to climate change, this unit will examine the complicated ways in which humans and Earth interact.

name: Movement and forces
description: Forceful, forcing, "may the force be with you!"—how do scientists define the term "force", and how do forces make things move? Learn how we can define and measure forces and motion to understand how things ranging from grains of sand to entire planets move.

name: Forces at a distance
description: Why does the moon orbit around the earth? How does a compass work? Here, you'll learn about forces that occur across a distance when objects are not touching each other. Explore gravitational, magnetic, and electric forces, how they affect objects, and how electromagnetism can be used to create magnets and electricity.

name: Energy
description: Did you know that energy exists in a variety of forms and can be transferred from one object to another? Here, you'll learn about kinetic and potential energy, how objects can gain or lose energy, and will explore some examples of energy transfer that we see in our everyday lives.

name: Waves
description: Let's surf into the phenomena of waves. From sunshine to Wifi to regulating our heartbeats, this physics phenomenon shapes our lives and our world in so many ways.

name: Biology foundations
description: Welcome to the amazing world of biology! Begin your journey with this unit, where you'll explore the properties of life, the scientific method, biological macromolecules, and biochemistry basics.

name: Cells
description: You, my friend, are made up of cells. Lots and lots of them. Jump in to learn more about prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells and the complex and beautiful structures inside them.

name: Energy and transport
description: Your cells are bustling hubs of activity! Every second, substances are being transported across membranes, molecules are being built up and broken down, and enzymes are catalyzing chemical reactions. In this unit, learn about these activities and how they come together to help cells carry out cellular respiration and photosynthesis, two of the most important biological processes on Earth.

name: Reproduction and cell division
description: New organisms don't just appear out of nowhere—they are the result of reproduction! In this unit, we'll learn about sexual and asexual reproduction, fertilization, and development. We'll also explore mitosis and meiosis, which are the cellular processes that allow organisms to grow and reproduce.

name: Classical genetics
description: Have you ever been told that you have your mother's eyes or grandfather's nose? Learn why traits run in families and how they're passed on. We'll look at Mendel's model of inheritance and learn how it's been revised and extended in the past 150 years.

name: Molecular genetics
description: DNA serves as the genetic material for all living organisms. Learn more about the structure and synthesis of this remarkable molecule, and how genes in your DNA provide instructions for building proteins.

name: Evolution
description: Discover the diversity of life on Earth and the forces that shape it! In this section, you can learn about evolution, natural selection, and the tree of life.

name: Human body systems
description: Your body is an amazing system! The human body is made up of groups of organs, called organ systems, that work together to keep the body in balance. In this section, we'll travel from the circulatory system, to the nervous system, to the immune system and beyond. Learn about the amazing biology that keeps your body ticking!

name: Ecology
description: Welcome to the fascinating subject of ecology! From population dynamics to biodiversity, this unit explores the complex web of interactions that make up our natural world.

name: Genes, cells, and organisms
description: Your body is an amazing system of interacting parts. In this unit, we'll go from micro to macro as we explore genes, cells, and organisms. Learn about cell specialization, DNA and proteins, and the organization of multipcellular organisms, all while gaining a deeper appreciation for what makes you, you!

name: Growth and feedback in organisms
description: From the smallest single-celled organisms to the largest and most complex, all life relies on the process of mitosis to grow and develop. In this unit, you'll learn about cell division and how organisms regulate their internal environments to stay healthy.

name: Matter and energy in organisms
description: In this unit, you'll learn the basics of photosynthesis, cellular respiration, and biomolecules. You'll learn about the chemical processes that make life possible, and you might just come away with a new appreciation for the complexity of the natural world!

name: Matter and energy in ecosystems
description: In this unit, you'll learn all about the way populations grow, the limits to their growth, and the way energy and matter move in ecosystems. You'll also explore the carbon cycle, a crucial process that keeps our planet in balance.

name: Interactions in ecosystems
description: Ecosystems are intricate webs of life that provide us with essential goods and services. In this unit, you'll learn about how ecosystems adapt and bounce back from changes, as well as how human activities can impact them in both positive and negative ways.

name: Inheritance and variation
description: Ready to learn about the blueprints of life? In this unit, we'll explore the basics of genetics, from how genes are expressed to how they're shuffled during meiosis. We'll also examine the incredible ways that both our genes and our environment can influence our traits and shape who we are.

name: Evolution and natural selection
description: This unit is all about evolution—one of the most important concepts in biology. Dive in to learn about the genetic, fossil, and anatomical evidence for evolution, and explore how natural selection shapes populations and group behaviors.

name: Adaptation and environmental change
description: In this unit, you'll learn about how species evolve and adapt to their surroundings. From the way populations change to survive in new environments, to the fascinating processes of speciation and extinction, you'll gain a deeper understanding of the natural world and the forces that shape it.

name: Biodiversity and human impacts
description: In this unit, you'll explore the complexities of human impacts on the environment. From habitat destruction to resource overuse, you'll learn about the challenges we face in preserving biodiversity. But don't worry, you'll also discover how science and technology can be our best allies in the fight against environmental problems.

name: Creativity in biology
description: Creativity isn't just important in the arts—it's important in STEM fields, too! In this unit, you'll hear from biology professionals as they talk about how they use creativity in their work, and about how you can think creatively about science, too.

name: One-dimensional motion
description: Moving.... in one dimension. Let's explore the ideas of displacement, velocity, and acceleration as we delve into the basics of mechanics.

name: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
description: The word force can take on different meanings—how is it used in science? Learn about what a force is and how a Isaac Newton's Laws of Motion changed the world's view of how forces and motion work.

name: Two-dimensional motion
description: Two is better than one, right?! Let's take our understanding of forces, motion, velocity, and acceleration to a second dimension as we explore more realistic—and fun—scenarios.

name: Uniform circular motion and gravitation
description: How does the spin cycle on your clothes dryer get most of the water out? What causes planets to orbit in a circular motion? The answer to these questions lies in the forces behind circular motion. Dive into a vortex of centripetal force, centripetal acceleration, and Newton's law of gravitation.

name: Work and energy
description: In physics, the work goes beyond 9-5. Let's see how physicists define the term "work", and how work relates to the concepts of kinetic energy, potential energy, conservation of energy, and mechanical advantage.

name: Linear momentum and collisions
description: What do you get when you multiply mass times velocity? Momentum! Momentum can explain—or predict—what happens when objects with different masses and velocities collide with one another. Let's bump our way into this important and relevant concept.

name: Torque and angular momentum
description: The wheels on the bus go round and round.... their axles, that is. Let's get into the physics of those bus wheels as we explore rotational motion, rotational inertia, torque, and angular momentum.

name: Simple harmonic motion
description: Remember swingsets? You can swing high on them, but you can't get the swing to do a full circle. This is because of harmonic motion, which keeps an object oscillating (moving back and forth) within a specific range of motion. Let's explore harmonic motion and its applications.

name: Waves
description: Let's surf into the phenomena of waves. From sunshine to Wifi to regulating our heartbeats, this physics phenomenon shapes our lives and our world in so many ways.

name: Sound
description: Why do sounds change as they get closer or further from you? Why does sound carry so well in—or on—water? Delve into the physics behind sound and sound waves as we explore these questions.

name: Static electricity
description: Electric forces hold together the atoms and molecules in your eyes which allow you to read this sentence. Take a moment and learn about the force that holds our bodies together.

name: DC Circuits
description: What's electricity, and how does it move through wires? Explore circuits and the effect of battery power, conductors, and resistors on electrical current. Learn how to use your understanding of electricity to explain the physics behind electronics and to even build your own electric motor!

name: Forces and motion
description: Understanding interactions between force, mass, acceleration, and momentum allows us to predict and how an object will move and comes in handy when we're designing things like airplanes or seismically-reinforced buildings. Let's start exploring what these terms mean and how they relate to one another!

name: Types of interactions
description: Force fields sounds like science fiction, but they are a part of everyday life. In fact, they're what keep your lights on, your papers magnetically attached to your fridge, and you from floating off into outer space. Learn about electromagnetism, gravity, and how forces can be modeled using vector fields.

name: Introduction to energy
description: We know how it feels to be energetic—but what is energy exactly, and how we can investigate it? Learn about the theory of energy, the different macroscopic forms it takes, and how the forms of energy are tied together at the microscopic scale.

name: Modeling energy
description: How high can you jump on that trampoline? Sure, you could just start hopping around, but physics gives us a safer option. Use your knowledge of energy, you can mathematically model energy of an object or system, such as a spring, to predict how systems will behave.

name: Wave properties
description: From surfing in the sunshine to streaming a concert on WiFi, waves make all sorts of things possible.  Learn about the basics of mechanical and electromagnetic waves, and explore how properties of waves are interconnected and how waves affect one another.

name: Electromagnetic radiation
description: Light rays, X-rays and gamma rays are all examples of electromagnetic radiation. Learn how the discovery of electromagnetic radiation and its properties have led to new physics concepts and technological applications. Explore the concept of wave-particle duality, interactions between electromagnetic radiation and matter, and emission spectra of electromagnetic radiation.

name: Information technologies
description: Today you can have a video conversation with someone halfway around the world, thanks to applications of physics! Learn how digital and analog information can be communicated through waves, and how many technologies are based on different types of waves.

name: Chemistry of life
description: In this unit, we'll explore the foundations of life itself, learning about macromolecules from proteins to nucleic acids. By the end, you'll have a better understanding of the chemical properties that make life possible.

name: Cell structure and function
description: Take your cellular knowledge to the next level! From organelles to membrane transport, this unit covers the facts you need to know about cells - the tiny building blocks of life.

name: Cellular energetics
description: In this unit, we'll tackle the energetics of the cell, exploring how enzymes function, how cells harvest energy, and how plants turn sunlight into sustenance.

name: Cell communication and cell cycle
description: Prepare to dive deep into the inner workings of cells! In this unit, you'll learn about how cells communicate with one another, how cells divide, and how problems can arise when these processes go wrong.

name: Heredity
description: Let's dive into the complex world of genetics! In this unit, you'll explore the intricacies of meiosis, learn the basics of Mendelian and non-Mendelian genetics, and discover how genes and the environment can interact to shape the traits we see.

name: Gene expression and regulation
description: DNA helps make us who we are, but how exactly does it work? In this unit, we'll examine the nitty gritty of replication, transcription, and translation, and learn how seemingly small mutations can have a big impact on our lives.

name: Natural selection
description: Are you ready to learn the ins and outs of evolution? From how natural selection drives change to the different ways species arise and go extinct, this unit will take you on an exciting journey through the history of life on Earth.

name: Ecology
description: Welcome to the fascinating subject of ecology! From population dynamics to biodiversity, this unit explores the complex web of interactions that make up our natural world.

name: Worked examples of AP®︎ Biology free response questions
description: Watch worked examples of free response questions from the 2015 AP®︎ Biology exam.

name: AP®︎ Biology standards mappings
description: Dig into the world of AP®︎ Biology and find out how our free course material aligns with the standards set by the College Board.

name: Atomic structure and properties
description: This unit explores the atomic theory of matter, the foundational premise of chemistry. Learn about moles and molar mass, mass spectrometry, electron configurations, periodic trends, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with more than 100 AP-aligned questions.

name: Molecular and ionic compound structure and properties
description: This unit examines how atomic structure relates to the macroscopic properties of substances. Learn about chemical bonding, Lewis diagrams, resonance and formal charge, VSEPR, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with more than 85 AP-aligned questions.

name: Intermolecular forces and properties
description: This unit explores the factors that determine the physical properties of matter. Learn about intermolecular forces, the ideal gas law, solutions and mixtures, chromatography, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with more than 165 AP-aligned questions.

name: Chemical reactions
description: This unit introduces chemical reactions, the processes that create and transform matter. Learn about net ionic equations, reaction stoichiometry, titration, common reaction types, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with 80 AP-aligned questions.

name: Kinetics
description: This unit focuses on rates of change in chemical reactions and the factors that influence them. Learn about rate laws, reaction mechanisms, collision theory, catalysis, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with 60 AP-aligned questions.

name: Thermodynamics
description: This unit examines the role of energy in physical and chemical processes. Learn about heat transfer, calorimetry, enthalpy of reaction, Hess’s law, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with more than 55 AP-aligned questions.

name: Equilibrium
description: This unit explores the how and why of chemical equilibrium. Learn about reversible reactions, the equilibrium constant, Le Châtelier's principle, solubility equilibria, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with more than 80 AP-aligned questions.

name: Acids and bases
description: This unit examines the role of chemical equilibrium in acid–base chemistry. Learn about pH and pOH, weak acids and bases, buffers, acid–base titrations, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with more than 70 AP-aligned questions.

name: Applications of thermodynamics
description: The unit connects the areas of kinetics, thermodynamics, equilibrium, and electrochemistry. Learn about entropy, Gibbs free energy, cell potential, electrolysis, and more. Practice what you’ve learned and study for the AP Chemistry exam with more than 70 AP-aligned questions.

name: The living world: ecosystems and biodiversity
description: This unit explores the Earth as a system with interdependent components, processes, and relationships. Learn about ecosystems, terrestrial and aquatic biomes, natural climate change, biogeochemical cycles, energy transfer, and biodiversity.

name: Populations
description: This unit examines the relationship between the type of species and the changes in habitat over time. Learn about generalist and specialist species, K-selected ad r-selected species, survivorship, carrying capacity, population growth, age structure, fertility, human population dynamics, and the demographic transition model.

name: Earth systems and resources
description: This unit explores Earth systems and resources that support life. Learn about plate tectonics, soil formation and erosion, soil composition and properties, earth's atmosphere, global wind patterns, watersheds, solar radiation and Earth's seasons, Earth's geography and climate, and El Nino and La Nina.

name: Land and water use
description: This unit explores human activities that disrupt ecosystems both positively and negatively and the methods employed to reduce impact. In it you will learn about the tragedy of the commons, clearcutting, the green revolution, impacts of agricultural practices, irrigation methods, pest control methods, meat production methods, impacts of overfishing, impacts of mining, impacts of urbanization, and ecological footprints.

name: Energy resources and consumption
description: This unit examines human use of renewable and nonrenewable sources of energy and its impact on the environment. Review Fuel types and uses, global energy consumption, distribution of natural resources, fossil fuels, nuclear power, energy from biomass, solar energy, hydroelectric power, geothermal energy wind energy, and energy conservation.

name: Atmospheric pollution
description: Air pollution has many sources and effects, both indoors and outdoors. This unit reviews photochemical smog, thermal inversion, atmospheric CO2 and particulates, indoor air pollutants, reduction of air pollutants, acid rain, and noise pollution.

name: Aquatic and terrestrial pollution
description: How can we keep trash out of our oceans? In this unit, we'll learn about pollution in water and on land. We'll explore the effects of pollutants on ecosystems and our health, and we'll discover the different ways we can reduce and treat the waste we produce.

name: Global change
description: What does it mean for climate change to be human-driven? In this unit, we'll explore the impacts that human activities have had on our atmosphere and oceans. We'll learn about processes such as ozone depletion, the greenhouse effect, and ocean acidification and examine their effects on Earth's biodiversity.

name: Kinematics and introduction to dynamics
description: Having a specific understanding of an object's position, acceleration, velocity, and motion comes in handy in situations ranging from bobsledding to launching rockets into outer space. Let's explore the concepts and equations that govern how objects move, and learn how to calculate the specifics of an object's motion.

name: Newton's laws
description: Which will fall faster, a feather or a brick? Unravel this mystery—and many more—as you explore Newton's Laws of Motion and their use in predicting the effects of forces on the motion of objects.

name: Circular motion and gravitation
description: From planning satellites' orbits around the earth to designing thrilling amusement park rides, understanding circular motion and gravity allows you to calculate, explain, and predict how pretty much anything that moves in a circle.

name: Energy and momentum
description: This unit explores energy, momentum, and the conservation of both quantities in a system. You'll explore how force and work are related, how energy exists in different forms, and how energy and momentum are connected.

name: Simple harmonic motion and rotational motion
description: Let's swing, buzz and rotate into the study of simple harmonic and rotational motion! Learn about the period and energy associated with a simple harmonic oscillator and the specific kinematic features of rotational motion.

name: Practice Passages: Critical Analysis and Reasoning Skills (CARS)
description: Get an introduction to the MCAT's Critical Analysis and Reasoning Skills section, and learn some strategies for sharpening your ability to evaluate information and form logical conclusions. You'll be well prepared to tackle, analyze, and draw out meaning from reading passages on a wide variety of topics.

name: Practice Passages: Biological and Biochemical Foundations of Living Systems
description: As a physician, you'll be reading plenty of scientific literature about the biology and biochemisty of various conditions. Build up your comprehension skills with some practice passages that focus on the intersection of biology and medicine.

name: Practice Passages: Chemical and Physical Foundations of Biological Systems
description: From medical imaging to blood analysis, chemistry and physics are everywhere in medicine. Let's dig into some reading passages about the physical science behind medical topics such as diseases, drug development, and devices.

name: Practice Passages: Psychological, Social, and Biological Foundations of Behavior
description: Factors affecting patients' behavior and psychological well-being have an impact on overall health, and are important for all physicians to consider. Hone your analytical skills as you investigate and interpret some passages on psychological, social, and biological foundations of behavior.

name: Foundation 1: Biomolecules
description: Zoom into the world of biomolecules as you explore the structure and function of proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, lipids, ATP, and more! Explore some of the ways that these molecules regulate inheritance and metabolism in all living things.

name: Foundation 2: Cells
description: Cells: the basic building blocks of life! Learn about the structure of living cells and how this allows them to carry out critical functions, including homeostasis, growth and reproduction. See how cells interact with one another and with other environmental factors, and how differentiation results in some cells' specialized structure and function.

name: Foundation 3: Organ systems
description: Nervous that your knowledge of organ systems is Skeletal? Don't be! After you Muscle your way through this unit on organ systems, you'll be able to discuss how specialized tissues are arranged into organs, and how different organ systems work together to maintain homeostasis, enable reproduction, and respond to environmental threats such as pathogens.

name: Foundation 4: Physical processes
description: From designing a better MRI machine to understanding heartbeat regulation, physics and chemistry concepts are everywhere in medicine! Here you'll review some of the basics of physics and chemistry, including mechanics, optics, electricity and magnetism, periodicity, and chemical equations, as you prepare to show your physical science prowess on the MCAT.

name: Foundation 5: Chemical processes
description: From amino acids to aldehydes, let's review some chemical concepts that are relevant to medicine. Delve into acids and bases, chemical bonding, types of organic molecules, and physical and thermochemistry as you get ready to crush these topics on the MCAT!

name: Foundation 6: Processing the environment
description: How do we use our senses to perceive and respond to our environments? Examine question from a few angles as we explore different types of sensory perception, frameworks of cognition, consciousness, attention, and memory, the role of language and communication, and how perception can be altered by factors such as drug dependency or lack of sleep.

name: Foundation 7: Behavior
description: The biological and psychological bases of behavior are important tools in understanding, empathizing with, and supporting your patients. Learn about the neural underpinnings of behavior, how personality and motivation are defined, and explore examples of common psychological disorders. Finally, investigate relationships between social factors and behavior, and how theories of learning relate to behavioral change.

name: Foundation 8: Individuals and society
description: As a healthcare professional, you'll need to understand the social factors that influence your patients' psychological development and health. Examine theories of self-identity, behavior attribution, and social behavior and interactions, as we explore how factors such as bias and discrimination can influence behavior and psychological well-being.

name: Foundation 9: Society and culture
description: Healthcare is a component of a complex and diverse society, and having a basic understanding of sociology, demographics, and culture will help you to be a culturally responsive practitioner who supports and empowers patients from all walks of life. This unit explores these ideas and more.

name: Foundation 10: Social inequality
description: In an ideal world, all patients would have equal access to the resources that they need to live long, healthy, fulfilling lives. But medicine today is practiced in a context of social inequality. Examine social inequality from a variety of angles, leaving you informed - and empowered to advocate for equal access and opportunity for those in your care.

name: Intro to JS: Drawing & Animation
description: Have you ever wondered what it takes to make drawings come to life? Well, we have to speak to our computer in a special language. In this unit, we will learn how to use the programming language JavaScript and Processing JavaScript to make our own drawings and animation.

name: Intro to HTML/CSS: Making webpages
description: Learn how to use HTML and CSS to make webpages. HTML is the markup language that you surround content with, to tell browsers about headings, lists, tables, and more. CSS is the stylesheet language that you style the page with, to tell browsers to change the color, font, layout, and more.

name: Intro to SQL: Querying and managing data
description: Learn how to use SQL to store, query, and manipulate data. SQL is a special-purpose programming language designed for managing data in a relational database, and is used by a huge number of apps and organizations.

name: Advanced JS: Games & Visualizations
description: Once you've taken Intro to JS, go here to learn techniques to help you make multi-scene programs, 3d graphics, button menus, and scored games.

name: Advanced JS: Natural Simulations
description: Once you've taken Intro to JS, you can go through this course to learn how to combine JS, ProcessingJS, and mathematical concepts to simulate nature in your programs. This course is a derivative of "The Nature of Code" book by Daniel Shiffman (natureofcode.com), used under CC BY-NC.

name: HTML/JS: Making webpages interactive
description: Once you've taken both Intro to JS and Intro to HTML/CSS, take this course to learn how use HTML/CSS with the JavaScript DOM API to make your webpages interactive.

name: HTML/JS: Making webpages interactive with jQuery
description: Learn how to use jQuery, the world's most popular JS browser library, to add interactivity to your webpages.

name: Meet the professional
description: What can you do with computer science and programming skills once you've learned them? We've invited people from all around the world and the industry to introduce themselves to you. Find out how diverse our field can be!

name: Digital information
description: How can my laptop hold so much information? Learn how computers store information digitally by using the binary number system. You’ll also be able to explain how computers convert analog to digital data, and ways that they can compress data into manageable file sizes.

name: The Internet
description: Discover the different components of the Internet, including the physical layer (Ethernet, Fiber, WiFi), different protocols (IP, TCP, UDP, DNS, HTTP), and the World Wide Web. You’ll learn how these components work together to connect people, and how initiatives are aiming to bridge the digital divide and get all of us online.

name: Programming
description: Programming is the way that we tell computers to do all the amazing things that they can do! Dig into the fundamentals of programming, including variables, strings, procedures, Boolean logic, randomness and repetition, and explore some examples of common programming languages, including JavaScript, Snap, and Python.

name: Algorithms
description: Learn to define algorithms, express them in flow chart and pseudocode, and assess their correctness and efficiency. See how algorithms can be used as shortcuts to solve problems that cannot be solved in a reasonable amount of time, and how this applies to undecidable problems and parallel and distributed computing.

name: Data analysis
description: Big data - it's everywhere! Here you'll learn ways to store data in files, spreadsheets, and databases, and will learn how statistical software can be used to analyze data for patterns and trends. You'll also learn how big data can be used to improve algorithms like translation, image recognition, and recommendations.

name: Simulations
description: You may not be a fortune teller, but you can use tools called simulations to predict what will happen in certain scenarios. This unit explores simulations, with interactive examples from various fields. Learn how to use random numbers and walk-through the process of creating a simple simulation.

name: Online data security
description: Let's surf safely! Become familiar with the concept of personal identifiable information (PII) and the ways in which PII can be tracked online. Learn how attackers can gain access to data and devices, and what steps you can take to shut down cybercriminals and keep your data and devices secure.

name: Computing innovations
description: Computing technology is constantly - and rapidly - evolving, and new innovations can sometimes yield unexpected outcomes. In this unit, you’ll consider the benefits and risks of a wide range of computing innovations, including social media, citizen science, smart sensors, and more.

name: Exam preparation
description: This unit provides exam preparation resources, including an overview of the exam format, a guide to practicing for the exam, and a vocabulary review. Get ready to crush the AP Computer Science Principles exam!

name: AP®︎ CSP standards mappings
description: Dig into the world of AP®︎ Computer Science Principles and find out how our free course material aligns with the standards set by the College Board.

name: Orientation
description: Welcome to Pixar in a Box! Learn how about the structure of this course, and the resources that it contains to support students and teachers.

name: The art of storytelling
description: What makes for a good story? Learn how a story's structure, characters, visuals, and cinematography contribute to a film's story, and how feedback helps to strengthen a film's storytelling.

name: The art of lighting
description: Without virtual lights, animated films would be as dark as a live action movie would be without actual lights.  Pixar’s Lighting Artists use light to support the emotion of the story and make the films look and feel believable. In this lesson you will learn about the properties of light and how different types of light sources are used to bring beauty, depth and emotion to Pixar films.

name: Simulation
description: A believable world frequently contains objects that need to move in a realistic way, but are too complicated or numerous to move individually “by hand” - things like leaves on a tree or hairs on a monster’s body. In this lesson, visitors will learn how Pixar uses computer programming to create believable simulated hair as seen in the film Brave.

name: Color science
description: Just as dialog, acting, and music are tools filmmakers use to convey meaning and emotion, color can be used to the same effect. But determining “color” is not as simple as saying “red” or “brown” because there are endless shades of color in the visible spectrum. In this lesson, you will learn how color is determined partly by the physics of light and partly by how our brains perceive it.

name: Virtual cameras
description: Just as live-action movies are made using cameras, Pixar uses virtual cameras to “film” their movies, with lenses that act like the real thing. In this lesson, you’ll experiment with different camera settings like F-stop, focal length and focus to create cool effects in scenes from “Inside Out.”

name: Effects
description: Pixar effects artists create explosions, fire, and water by breaking them down into millions of tiny particles and controlling them using computer programming. In this lesson, you’ll use basic physics to create mini-special effects like flowing water and exploding fireworks.

name: Patterns
description: To make the surfaces of characters or objects seem believable, artists at Pixar take basic patterns and use computer graphics to make those patterns more random. You’ll get to use randomness in this lesson, when you make your very own dinosaur skin!

name: Rigging
description: “Rigging” is what Pixar artists call the process that gives characters movement, and it’s a crucial step in making them more realistic and human (even if they’re not actually humans).
